schools.name: College of Arts and Sciences
schools.description: The College of Arts and Sciences offers the Bachelor of Arts in a range of humanities and social science majors and the Bachelor of Science in social sciences and natural sciences fields. It also administers a variety of departmental and interdisciplinary minors.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Complete a minimum of 175 quarter units of credit

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Satisfy the requirements of the undergraduate Core Curriculum and the major.

schools.name: Leavey School of Business
schools.description: The Leavey School of Business confers the Bachelor of Science in Commerce with majors in accounting, accounting and information systems, economics, finance, individual studies, management, marketing, and management information systems. It also offers departmental minors in business analytics, management information systems, marketing, and real estate; and interdisciplinary minors in entrepreneurship, international business, retail studies, and sustainable food systems. To earn the B.S. in Commerce, students must complete the University Core Curriculum, the Leavey School core curriculum, a departmental major, and minimum unit requirements.

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Total quarter‑units for B.S. in Commerce
Upper‑division quarter‑units for B.S. in Commerce

otherRequirements.requirementDescription:
Undergraduate Core Curriculum: complete Critical Thinking & Writing; Cultures & Ideas; Second Language; Mathematics (MATH30 or MATH11, or MATH35 for life‑sciences double majors); Religion, Theology & Culture; Ethics (MGMT6 or PHIL26); Civic Engagement (MGMT162 plus MGMT6 or PHIL26); Diversity; Arts; Social Science (ECON1); Natural Science; Science, Technology, and Society (OMIS34); Experiential Learning for Social Justice; Advanced Writing (BUSN179); Pathways (≥16 units in a chosen Pathway).  
Leavey School Core Curriculum – Lower Division: BUSN70 and OMIS15; BUSN85; ECON1, 2, 3; MGMT71; ACTG11 and 12; Data Analysis (OMIS40 & OMIS41 or OMIS40 & ECON41 & ECON42); Information Systems (OMIS34 or, for MIS majors, OMIS30 or OMIS31 plus a Science, Technology & Society course).  
Leavey School Core Curriculum – Upper Division: FNCE121; MGMT160; MKTG181; OMIS108; Capstone (MGMT162).  
Prerequisites: all prerequisites must be completed or in progress before enrolling in the dependent course.  
Individual Studies Major Petition: full‑time at SCU ≥1 year; minimum 3.0 GPA; petition must include program description, justification for uniqueness, plan of study with ≥8 upper‑division courses beyond Core, and advisor support; approval by faculty director and, if needed, other departments.

schools.name: School of Engineering
schools.description: The School of Engineering confers the degree of Bachelor of Science with majors in Bioengineering, Civil Engineering, Computer Science and Engineering, Web Design and Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, General Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering. Specialized B.S. programs in Civil Engineering, Computer Science and Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Electrical Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering are accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET; the B.S. in Computer Science and Engineering is also accredited by the Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET. The B.S. programs in Bioengineering, General Engineering, and Web Design and Engineering are not yet ABET‑accredited. The school offers minors in Engineering, Computer Science and Engineering, Construction Management, Electrical Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Aerospace Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Bioengineering, Healthcare Innovation and Design, and Technical Innovation, Design Thinking, and the Entrepreneurial Mindset. All undergraduate engineering programs require extensive course sequences in mathematics and natural science, and prerequisites for all engineering courses are strictly enforced.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Critical Thinking & Writing: One two‑course sequence in composition: CTW 1 and 2; Advanced Writing: ENGL 181; Religion, Theology & Culture 1, 2, 3: Three approved courses; Cultures & Ideas 1 & 2: One approved course sequence; Cultures & Ideas 3: One approved course; Mathematics and Natural Science: Specified in each major; Second Language: Recommended proficiency, satisfied by two years high school study; Social Science: One approved course; Civic Engagement: Either one approved course, or ENGR 1 plus a senior design project; Ethics: One approved course in general or applied ethics; Diversity: One approved course; Arts: Either one approved course, or ENGL 181 plus a senior design project; Science, Technology & Society: Either one approved course (including ENGR 1), or ENGL 181 plus a senior design project; Experiential Learning for Social Justice: One approved course or activity; Pathways: Three approved courses with a common theme for a declared Pathway.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Anthropology
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Anthropology offers a Bachelor of Science in Anthropology, providing students with analytical skills for advanced study or professional careers. The department also offers a minor, several optional emphasis programs, and an honors thesis option.

majors.name: Anthropology
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Anthropology
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: ANTH1 & ANTH2 & ANTH3 & (ANTH4 | ANTH5 | ANTH6 | ANTH7 | ANTH12A) & (ANTH50 | ENVS50) & ANTH110 & (MATH8 | BIOL160 | ENVS110 | PSYC105 | POLI101) & (ANTH111 | ANTH112 | ANTH113) & (ENVS116 | ENVS116A | ETHN165 | PHSC50 | PSYC105 | BIOL160 | ENVS110 | WGST102 | ANTH111 | ANTH112 | ANTH113) & ANTH114 & ANTH198 & 6(ANTH130-139 | ANTH140-149 | ANTH150-179 | ANTH173 | ANTH184 | ANTH185 | ANTH186 | ANTH187 | ANTH188 | ANTH189)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Attend six Anthropology Speaker Series events

otherNotes: Course selections for the six upper-division electives must include at least one course from each of the Archaeology, Biological Anthropology, and Cultural Anthropology categories.

minors.name: Anthropology
minors.description: Minor in Anthropology
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ANTH1 | ANTH2) & ANTH3 & 1(ANTH1-99) & 2(ANTH100-199)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Attend four Anthropology Speaker Series events

emphases.name: Applied Anthropology
emphases.description: Prepares students to use anthropological knowledge and skills to address critical human issues in non‑academic careers (e.g., health, development, environment, government, business, education, immigration, poverty).

emphases.name: Archaeology
emphases.description: Focuses on understanding the human past and methods of archaeological study, suited for cultural resource management or graduate study in archaeology.

emphases.name: Biological
emphases.description: Provides in‑depth training in biological anthropology, examining interdisciplinary aspects of human evolution and modern human diversity.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Art and Art History
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Art and Art History offers degree programs leading to the Bachelor of Arts in two undergraduate majors, Art History and Studio Art. Courses in both disciplines build a thorough understanding of the history and practice of art. Faculty encourage interdisciplinary connections through course offerings that fulfill Core Curriculum requirements and honors program participation, as well as study abroad, internships, and symposia.

majors.name: Art History
majors.description: Students examine human visual expression across space and time, learning to analyze visual and material culture, conduct advanced research and writing, and prepare for careers or graduate work in art history.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: One upper-division ARTH course must be an advanced writing course.

otherNotes: Only 4 units of ARTH 98/198 or ARTH 194 may count toward the art history major or minor.
No more than three study abroad courses may be accepted, and only one upper-division study abroad course may fulfill the upper-division ARTH requirement.
Only approved study abroad courses from the equivalency database may be accepted as transfer credit.

majors.name: Studio Art
majors.description: Students develop conceptual and technical competence in fine and commercial arts, build a senior exhibit and artist’s statement, and present work in exhibitions and regional conferences.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ARTS30 & ARTS74 & (ARTS32 | ARTS72) & (ARTS33 | ARTS63 | ARTS64) & 6((ARTS1-199) & !(ARTS194 | ARTS198)) & 3(ARTS100-199) & 4(ARTH1-199) & ARTS100 & ARTS190 & ARTS196)

otherRequirements.requirementName: Study Abroad and Transfer Credit Restrictions
otherRequirements.requirementDescription: No more than half of elective requirements may be study abroad courses; only one art history study abroad course may count; only approved equivalency courses may be accepted as transfer credit.

minors.name: Animation and Illustration
minors.description: A nine-course minor emphasizing foundational studio courses, animation and illustration technique, and one art history elective.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ARTS30 & ARTS74 & (ARTS33 | ARTS63 | ARTS64) & ARTS81 & ARTS181 & (ARTS131 | ARTS173 | ARTS179 | ARTS182 | COMM30 | COMM130) & 2((ARTS1-199) & !(ARTS190 | ARTS194 | ARTS196)) & ARTH1-199)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students must declare the minor by Fall of junior year; cannot also declare certain other art minors or a studio art major; no art history study abroad accepted; up to four approved studio art study abroad courses may count.

minors.name: Art History
minors.description: A seven-course minor in art history, including two lower-division, one studio art, three upper-division, and one additional art history course.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Only 4 units of ARTH 98/198 may count; no more than three study abroad courses; only one upper-division study abroad course toward the upper-division requirement; only approved equivalency courses may be accepted.

minors.name: Arts Management
minors.description: An eight-course minor combining arts management–designated art history courses with English, management, and marketing courses, plus an internship.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (3(ARTH1-199) & 2(ARTH100-199) & (ENGL100GR | ENGL101 | ENGL112) & 2(MGMT160 | MGMT170) & (MKTG181 | MKTG186 | MKTG190) & ARTH198)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Participation in a senior‐year culminating event, such as the Annual Art History Symposium, is required.

otherNotes: Students must declare the minor by Fall of junior year; cannot also declare the art history minor or major.
Only one study abroad art history course may be accepted; only approved equivalency courses may be accepted.

minors.name: Graphic Design
minors.description: A nine‐course minor focusing on foundational, three‐dimensional, design electives, and one art history course.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ARTS30 & (ARTS33 | ARTS63 | ARTS64) & ARTS74 & 2(ARTS170 | ARTS173 | ARTS175 | ARTS177 | ARTS178 | ARTS180) & 2((ARTS1-199) & !(ARTS190-199)) & (ARTS70 | ARTS75) & 1((ARTH1-199) & !(ARTH11A | ARTH12A | ARTH194)))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students must declare the minor by Fall of junior year; cannot also declare other art minors or a studio art major; no more than four study abroad courses; art history study abroad courses are not accepted; only approved equivalency courses may be accepted.

minors.name: Studio Art
minors.description: A seven‐course minor including two foundation studio courses, four electives, and one art history course.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: ((ARTS30 | ARTS32 | ARTS35-57 | ARTS70 | ARTS72) & (ARTS33 | ARTS63 | ARTS64) & 4((ARTS1-199) & !(ARTS194)) & 1((ARTH1-199) & !(ARTH11A | ARTH12A | ARTH194)))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: No more than three study abroad courses; art history study abroad courses are not accepted; only approved equivalency courses may be accepted; cannot also declare certain art minors or a studio art major.

emphases.name: Arts Management
emphases.description: An optional emphasis for Art History majors combining arts management–designated ARTH courses with English, management, marketing, and an internship.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: (3(ARTH1-199) & 1(ENGL100GR | ENGL101 | ENGL112) & 2(MGMT160 | MGMT170 | MGMT174) & 1(MKTG181 | MKTG186 | MKTG190) & ARTH198)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Completion of the emphasis will be noted on the student’s transcript.

emphases.name: Graphic Design
emphases.description: An optional emphasis for Studio Art majors in graphic design electives.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: ((ARTS70 | ARTS75) & 2(ARTS170 | ARTS173 | ARTS175 | ARTS177 | ARTS178 | ARTS180))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Completion of the emphasis will be noted on the student’s transcript.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Biology
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Biology offers courses for non‐majors and life‐science majors, from introductory through advanced levels, leading to the B.S. in Biology. The major provides core concepts of modern biological thought, critical skills in laboratory and field research, and preparation for graduate, medical, or professional study and careers in teaching, research, and business. Students are encouraged to work on faculty research (BIOL 195, BIOL 198).

majors.name: Biology
majors.description: A comprehensive program building foundational and advanced skills in modern biology, including laboratory and field experience, for careers or further study.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (BIOL1A & BIOL1B & BIOL1C) & (CHEM11 & CHEM12 & CHEM31 & CHEM32 & CHEM33) & ((PHYS11 & PHYS12 & PHYS13) | (PHYS31 & PHYS32 & PHYS33)) & ((MATH35 & MATH36) | (MATH11 & MATH12)) & BIOL101 & 7(BIOL100-199)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students must take at least five upper-division biology courses with a laboratory component.

minors.name: Biology
minors.description: A sequence of foundational and advanced biology courses, including chemistry prerequisites, for students seeking a minor in Biology.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (BIOL1A & BIOL1B & BIOL1C) & (CHEM11 & CHEM12 & CHEM31) & 3(BIOL100-199)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students must take at least two upper-division biology courses with a laboratory component.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Chemistry and Biochemistry
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry offers B.S. degrees in Chemistry and Biochemistry (including ACS‑certified options) and a B.A. in Chemistry. Accredited by the American Chemical Society, the programs prepare students for graduate study and careers in chemistry, biochemistry, health professions, law, business, and teaching. Undergraduate research is emphasized, and curricula are flexible for study abroad. A minor in Chemistry is also available.

majors.name: Bachelor of Science in Chemistry
majors.description: The standard B.S. in Chemistry provides broad training across all disciplines of chemistry, including core lecture and lab courses, research, electives, and seminars.

majors.description: The B.A. in Chemistry emphasizes flexibility and electives, ideal for pre‑medical, pre‑teaching, or liberal arts interests.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Child Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Child Studies major prepares undergraduates for careers working with children and families in school or community settings through a curriculum grounded in social justice, anti-racist, and cultural competence perspectives. Majors engage extensively with local schools and community programs and are equipped for graduate study and professions such as teaching, social work, counseling, psychology, law, and nonprofit work.

majors.name: Child Studies
majors.description: A Bachelor of Science major focusing on child‐family relations, developmental processes, and advocacy in educational and community contexts.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (CHST3 & CHST4 & CHST5 & CHST6 & CHST11 & CHST12 & CHST75 & CHST100 & CHST101 & CHST102 & CHST104 & CHST106 & CHST180 & CHST181 & CHST182 & PSYC2 & PSYC185 & 1(CHST66 | CHST109 | CHST114 | CHST115 | CHST138 | CHST154Y | CHST190 | CHST199 | ENVS131 | PSYC134 | PSYC172))

deptsAndPrograms.name: Classics
deptsAndPrograms.description: Classics is the study of all aspects of the life and culture of ancient Greece and Rome in their Mediterranean context and their enduring relevance to our lives. The department offers all levels of ancient Greek and Latin, as well as courses in literature, history, art, mythology, philosophy, religion, ethics, government, science, architecture and engineering. Latin or ancient Greek may be taken to satisfy the second‐language requirement.

majors.name: Classics
majors.description: Bachelor of Arts in Classics, offered in three tracks: Classical Languages and Literatures, Classical Studies, and Ancient Studies.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must also fulfill undergraduate Core Curriculum requirements for the B.A. degree.

otherNotes: Approved courses toward major include all CLAS‑prefix courses and listed cross‑listed courses (ARTH 104, 106, 110, 152; PHIL 14, 141; POLI 111); other ancient‑world courses may count with chair approval.

minors.name: Classics
minors.description: Interdisciplinary minor in Classics, offered in three tracks: Classical Languages and Literatures, Classical Studies, and Ancient Studies.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students who major in Classics must minor in a different track.

emphases.name: Classical Languages and Literatures
emphases.description: Intensive study of ancient Greek and Latin languages and literatures.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: 9(CLAS100-199) & (CLAS197A & CLAS197B)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: First‐year proficiency in both ancient Greek and Latin.

emphases.name: Classical Studies
emphases.description: Balanced combination of language (Greek or Latin) and other Classics courses.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Six classes in either Latin or Greek (may include the elementary sequence, but not both).

otherNotes: Six additional Classics courses required, at least four must be upper‐division.
Includes CLAS 197A and CLAS 197B.

emphases.name: Ancient Studies
emphases.description: Survey courses in ancient civilization plus additional non‐language Classics courses.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: (CLAS5 | CLAS60 | CLAS61)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Eleven non‐language Classics courses, at least seven must be upper‐division.

otherNotes: Includes CLAS 197A and CLAS 197B.

emphases.name: Classical Languages and Literatures
emphases.description: Advanced study of ancient Greek or Latin for the minor.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Five upper‑division courses in either Latin or Greek (Latin 3 or Greek 3 may count as an upper‑division course).

emphases.name: Classical Studies
emphases.description: Combination of one language course and Classics electives.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Latin 3 or Greek 3, or one upper‐division Greek or Latin course.

otherNotes: Four additional Classics courses required, at least two must be upper‐division.

emphases.name: Ancient Studies
emphases.description: Introductory survey courses plus Classics electives for the minor.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: (CLAS5 | CLAS60 | CLAS61)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Four non‐language Classics courses, at least two must be upper‐division.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Communication
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Communication offers a program leading to a B.A. in Communication. Students explore theories, research methods, responsibilities, institutional structures, and effects of mass, interpersonal, strategic, global, and computer-mediated communication. The curriculum integrates theory and practice to prepare students for careers in media, entertainment, technology, journalism, nonprofit industries, or for graduate study. The department also supports minors in Digital Filmmaking and Journalism, encourages study abroad (up to two approved courses count as upper-division electives), and promotes internships for hands-on experience.

majors.name: Communication
majors.description: A flexible major combining four foundational courses, three intermediate courses, and upper-division electives to prepare students for a wide variety of communication careers or graduate study.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (COMM1 & COMM2 & COMM3 & COMM4) & 3(COMM10 | COMM30 | COMM50 | COMM60 | COMM80) & (COMM100 & COMM101 & COMM197) & 6(COMM102-189 | COMM198)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: All courses used to fulfill major requirements must be four‑ or five‑unit letter‑grade courses; practicum courses (COMM190–195) do not count toward the major.

otherNotes: Up to two approved study abroad courses may count as upper-division electives.
Students are encouraged to complete off‑campus internships, which may count as department electives.

minors.name: Journalism
minors.description: The Journalism minor provides foundations in news reporting, writing, ethics, and digital storytelling, emphasizing professional skills for a democratic society.

minors.name: Digital Filmmaking
minors.description: The Digital Filmmaking minor teaches students production, screenwriting, editing, and critical analysis skills to create documentaries, short films, and other content through social‑justice informed storytelling.

emphases.description: Examines leadership as a process of social influence through communication, developing competencies in effective messaging, conflict management, intercultural communication, ethics, and critical analysis of leadership for social change.

emphases.name: Journalism

deptsAndPrograms.name: Economics
deptsAndPrograms.description: As one of the social sciences, economics studies how individual choices—as consumers and producers, savers and investors, managers and employees, citizens and voters—combine to determine how society uses its scarce resources to produce and distribute goods and services. This practical discipline provides insights into issues such as the determinants of wealth and poverty, unemployment, inflation, international trade, and economic growth; as well as success and failure in the marketplace. The rigorous, systematic analysis that the study of economics brings to bear on these and other real‑world issues provides excellent preparation for careers in both the private and public sectors, as well as for graduate study in economics, business, public policy, and law.

majors.name: Economics
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Economics
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ECON1 | ECON1E) & ECON2 & ECON3 & ((MATH11 & MATH12) | (MATH30 & MATH31)) & (OMIS40 | MATH122 | MATH8 | AMTH108) & ECON41 & ECON42 & (ECON113 & ECON114 & ECON115 & (ECON181 | ECON182)) & 5(ECON100-199)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: At least two of the five upper‑division economics electives must be completed after ECON113 and ECON115.

otherNotes: Unless otherwise noted, a grade of C‑ or better in ECON1, ECON2, and ECON3 is required for all upper‑division economics courses.

minors.name: Economics
minors.description: The economics minor provides foundational and intermediate study in economics along with two additional upper‑division electives and a calculus prerequisite.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: ECON1 & ECON2 & ECON3 & ECON113 & ECON115 & 2(ECON100-199) & (MATH11 | MATH30)

emphases.name: Data Analysis for Economics
emphases.description: Provides a structured course of study for economics majors to develop econometrics and data analysis skills and apply them to economic issues.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: ECON43 & (ECON173 | ECON174) & 3(ECON134 | ECON135 | ECON142 | ECON150 | ECON151 | ECON154 | ECON166 | ECON186 | ECON187 | ECON188)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: One (and only one) of the courses in list C may be substituted with an approved course in another social science or business discipline with a significant data analysis component, or an independent study course with a substantial data analysis component (4 or 5 units). Substitutions must be approved by the Concentration advisor.

otherNotes: All upper‑division courses in the concentration can count as upper‑division electives toward the economics major.
Currently pre‑approved substitutions: CSCI183, ENVS117, OMIS114, OMIS150.
Non‑economics courses will not count as one of the upper‑division electives toward the economics major.

emphases.name: Mathematical Economics
emphases.description: Requires additional advanced mathematics and economic theory courses beyond the standard major requirements.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: MATH11 & MATH12 & MATH13 & MATH14 & MATH53 & AMTH106 & 3(ECON170 | ECON171 | ECON172 | ECON173 | ECON174 | ECON187 | ECON188)
otherNotes: Students completing this concentration take MATH11 and MATH12 instead of MATH30 and MATH31 for the major requirements.

deptsAndPrograms.name: English
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of English affords students a rich undergraduate education in the liberal arts centered on literature, cultural studies, and writing. Critical, professional, or creative writing projects are integral to every course in the English major. Students and faculty discuss and write about British, American, and global literature, technical and professional communication, new media, and film. A range of theoretical approaches are used, sometimes with a focus on visual rhetoric and cultural studies.

majors.name: English
majors.description: An undergraduate major that centers on literature, cultural studies, and writing, preparing students to read and write critically with intellectual flexibility for academic and professional challenges.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ENGL14 & ENGL15 & ENGL16)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Two historically grounded literary or cultural studies courses (at least one before 1800); a three‑course concentration in literary/cultural studies (at least two upper‑division); a three‑course concentration in writing (professional writing & new media, or creative writing, or individually defined; at least two upper‑division); one upper‑division course in theory, or gender/sexuality, or ethnic/global studies; and one senior seminar.

minors.name: English
minors.description: A minor that introduces students to critical reading and writing through foundational and elective English courses.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ENGL14 | ENGL15) & ENGL16

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Five English electives, four of which must be upper‑division.

minors.name: Creative Writing
minors.description: Provides students with a coherent course of study in the writing of poetry, fiction, and creative nonfiction.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ENGL71 & ENGL72 & 2(ENGL91) & 3(ENGL73 | ENGL74 | ENGL170 | ENGL171 | ENGL172 | ENGL173 | ENGL175 | ENGL176 | ENGL177 | ENGL179 | ENGL179AW) & (ENGL171 | ENGL172))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: No more than two courses from the English major may be used to fulfill these requirements.

minors.name: Professional Writing
minors.description: Focuses on the theories, ethics, and practice of writing in industry and public contexts.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ENGL16 & (ENGL198A | ENGL189) & 5(ENGL19 | ENGL20 | ENGL25 | ENGL26 | ENGL100 | ENGL101 | ENGL103 | ENGL104 | ENGL105 | ENGL106 | ENGL107 | ENGL108 | ENGL109 | ENGL110 | ENGL111 | ENGL112 | ENGL113 | ENGL114 | ENGL115 | ENGL116 | ENGL181))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: No more than two courses from the English major may be used to fulfill these requirements.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Environmental Studies and Sciences
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Environmental Studies and Sciences offers interdisciplinary programs leading to a Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science or Environmental Studies, as well as a minor in Environmental Studies.  The programs combine core science and social‐science courses with hands‐on experiences including colloquia (ENVS 188), a sophomore seminar (ENVS 198), internships or research, and a two‐quarter senior capstone.  Students are encouraged to study abroad; up to two approved study‑abroad courses may count toward ESS requirements.

majors.name: Environmental Science
majors.description: An interdisciplinary BS in Environmental Science that combines foundational science courses, electives, and practical experience through internship and capstone.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ENVS21 & ENVS22 & ENVS23 & (MATH11 | MATH35) & (CHEM11 & CHEM12 & CHEM31) & (ENVS79 | PHIL29) & (ENVS100 & ENVS101 & ENVS122 & ENVS198) & (ENVS110 | BIOL160) & (ENVS116 | CENG160) & ENVS188 & (BIOL1A | BIOL1B | BIOL1C | PHYS11 | PHYS12 | PHYS13 | PHYS31 | PHYS32 | PHYS33))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: One selection from the approved list of departmental upper‑division social science courses; six upper‑division environmental science electives (at least three labs: minimum two biological science courses, minimum two physical science courses, up to two other electives); an approved 100‑hour internship

majors.name: Environmental Studies
majors.description: An interdisciplinary BS in Environmental Studies emphasizing social, political, and ethical perspectives alongside natural science foundations, plus practical experience through internship and capstone.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ENVS21 & ENVS22 & ENVS23 & (ANTH50 | ENVS50) & (ENVS79 | PHIL29) & (ENVS100 & ENVS101 & ENVS122 & ENVS198) & ENVS111 & (ENVS116 | CENG160) & ENVS188)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: One selection from approved statistics courses (ENVS 110 preferred); five upper‑division electives (one natural science lab, two to four additional department electives, up to two electives outside the department); an approved 100‑hour internship

minors.name: Environmental Studies
minors.description: Provides foundational coursework in environmental science, methods, social/political/legal perspectives, ethics, and electives.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ENVS21 & ENVS22 & ENVS23 & ENVS188)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: One methods course; one social, political, or legal perspectives course; one ethical or spiritual dimensions course; one additional inside elective; two additional electives drawn from inside or outside the department

deptsAndPrograms.name: Ethnic Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: Ethnic Studies is a compelling and dynamic discipline devoted to the critical examination of race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, class, and intersecting modes of inequality as experienced by historically marginalized populations. It fosters intersectional and interdisciplinary inquiry across fields such as education, economic development, immigration, labor, media and popular culture, and focuses on both U.S. and transnational contexts. The department offers a B.S. major and four minors, preparing students for careers in business, community service, education, law, medicine, social work, politics, and government, as well as graduate study in racial and ethnic justice.

majors.name: Ethnic Studies
majors.description: Provides advanced and concentrated training in racial and ethnic studies, with coursework clustered in the upper division around six themes: Community Engagement and Social Movements; Race, Law, Politics, and Policy; Intersectionality and Hybridity; Inequality and Education; Immigration, Transnationalism, and Globalization; and Social and Cultural Analysis.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Six upper‑division courses selected from at least four of the six thematic categories; no class may be used to fulfill more than one category. Plus one upper‑division elective (in Ethnic Studies or from an approved list), and capstone via ETHN 198 or by a research project in an upper‑division seminar.

minors.name: Ethnic Studies
minors.description: Provides foundational exposure to critical examination of race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, and intersecting inequalities through lower‑ and upper‑division coursework.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Consult with the Ethnic Studies Department Chair to determine applicability of courses taken at other institutions or in study abroad programs.

minors.description: Focuses on the histories, cultures, and sociopolitical experiences of African American/Black communities.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: A service‑learning course, internship, or equivalent work directly engaged with African American/Black communities.

minors.name: Asian American Studies
minors.description: Examines the histories, cultures, and experiences of Asian American, Pacific Islander, and South Asian communities.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: 2(ETHN40 | ETHN41 | ETHN50 | ETHN51) & 1(ETHN5 | ETHN55 | ETHN59 | ETHN60 | ETHN65 | ETHN69 | ETHN70 | ETHN96) & 4(ETHN100-199)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: A service‑learning course, internship, or equivalent work directly engaged with Asian American, Pacific Islander, or South Asian communities.

minors.description: Studies the histories, cultures, and sociopolitical experiences of Chicana/o/x and Latina/o/x communities.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: A service‑learning course, internship, or equivalent work directly engaged with Latina/o/x communities.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Gender and Sexuality Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Gender and Sexuality Studies offers an integrated, interdisciplinary approach to understanding the social and cultural constructions of gender and sexuality. It brings together scholarship on women and gender, feminist theory, and intersecting systems of power, preparing students for leadership roles in diverse workplaces, graduate study, and careers involving gender justice.

majors.name: Gender and Sexuality Studies
majors.description: The WGST major requires 13 courses: an introductory Principles of WGST course or sequence, four required upper‑division courses (WGST 101, WGST 102, WGST 105, WGST 190), a three‑course concentration in one of three thematic areas, and five electives.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: 1((WGST1A & WGST2A) | (WGST11A & WGST12A) | WGST25 | WGST50 | WGST51 | WGST52 | (WGST59 | ETHN59) | (WGST112 | ETHN154)) & (WGST101 & WGST102 & WGST105 & WGST190)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: A three‑course concentration in one of three areas: Cultural Politics of Representation; Power, Rights, and Society; or Sexualities, Body Politics, and Social Structures

otherNotes: Five electives

minors.name: Gender and Sexuality Studies
minors.description: The WGST minor requires six courses, at least three upper‑division, including one Principles of WGST course or sequence, one intermediate course (WGST 101 or WGST 102), one advanced course (WGST 105 or WGST 190), and three electives.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: 1((WGST1A & WGST2A) | (WGST11A & WGST12A) | WGST50 | WGST51 | WGST52 | (WGST59 | ETHN59) | (WGST112 | ETHN154)) & 1(WGST101 | WGST102) & 1(WGST190 | WGST105)

deptsAndPrograms.name: History
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of History offers a major program that provides students with an understanding of the human experience through analysis of evidence from both the recent and more distant past. History majors acquire essential analytical skills, thematic and geographical knowledge, and are prepared for careers in education, journalism, media, government, law, business, and international affairs.

majors.name: History
majors.description: The history major consists of 13 department courses—four lower‑division and nine upper‑division—that develop skills in discovering, organizing, and analyzing the forces that shape the contemporary world.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: From among the student’s lower‑ and upper‑division courses (excluding HIST100 and HIST101S), at least one course from four of the following six fields: Global History; the United States and Canada; Latin America; Europe; East/South Asia; Africa/West Asia.

otherNotes: One seminar course must be taken after completion of HIST101S and 115 quarter‑unit university credit.
History majors may be selected for graduation with Honors in History (minimum 3.5 GPA in history courses and completion of HIST197 approved by the faculty honors committee).
Students can complete directed reading/research (HIST199) with permission of the department chair and instructor.
Hybrid courses: lower‑division hybrid courses are worth 4 units; upper‑division hybrid courses are worth 5 units and include additional assignments.

minors.name: History
minors.description: The minor in history requires seven department courses, at least four of which must be upper‑division.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: At least four of the seven courses must be upper‑division (HIST100-199).

deptsAndPrograms.name: Individual Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Individual Studies Program (ISP) allows students to design a multidisciplinary course of study leading to a B.A. or a B.S. (social science). Students must choose courses from a wide variety of existing disciplines, with a strong preference for regular courses over independent-study or directed readings. Study abroad courses may be used for up to four courses in the plan of study. Students must secure a faculty advisor whose expertise aligns with their proposed study area, and the advisor oversees coursework approval and annual advising.

majors.name: Individual Studies
majors.description: A customizable, multidisciplinary major in which the student proposes a coherent plan of study across multiple disciplines, approved and overseen by a faculty advisor.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription:
• Be a full‑time student at SCU for at least one year
• Have fewer than 111 quarter units of academic work completed at the time of application
• Have a minimum 3.0 GPA
• Submit a petition to the ISP director including:
  – A clear, conceptually refined description of the proposed program
  – An argument showing no existing major meets the student’s objectives
  – A plan of study listing courses, seminars, internships that fulfill the objectives and Core Curriculum
  – Identification of a faculty advisor whose expertise aligns with the proposed study

otherNotes: Curriculum should draw from a significant number of different disciplines.
Strong preference for existing courses; independent‑study/directed readings are secondary.
No more than four courses in the plan of study may be study‑abroad courses.
Students must identify and secure a faculty advisor in good standing whose expertise intersects with their proposed study area.
The faculty advisor is responsible for approving coursework, substitutions if necessary, and providing at least annual advising (spring quarter).
Students should begin by meeting with the program director for administrative instructions.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Mathematics and Computer Science
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Mathematics and Computer Science offers B.S. degrees in Mathematics and Computer Science with various emphases. It also provides courses for other majors, supports talent development, seminars, research, and preparation for graduate study, teaching, or industry careers.

majors.name: Mathematics
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Mathematics with optional emphases; prepares students for graduate study, teaching, or careers in industry.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (CSCI10) & (MATH11 & MATH12 & MATH13 & MATH14 & MATH23 & MATH51 & MATH52 & MATH53) & (PHYS31 & PHYS32) & 7(((CSCI162 | MATH100-189) & !(MATH100 | MATH190-199)))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: ECON 170 or 173 may substitute for PHYS 32; PHYS 11 and 12 may substitute for PHYS 31 and 32 with approval.

otherNotes: Must include at least one upper‑division course in each of these categories: analysis (MATH 102/105/153), algebra (MATH 103/111), and geometry/discrete/applied (MATH 101/113/174, MATH 176/177, MATH 122/125/141/144/146/155/166).
At least four of the required upper‑division courses must be taken at SCU.
A single upper‑division course may not satisfy two majors or minors.

majors.name: Computer Science
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science; students choose one of several emphases.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (MATH11 & MATH12 & MATH13 & MATH14 & MATH51 & MATH53) & (CSCI10 & CSCI60 & CSCI61 & CSCI62) & 1(PHYS31 | CHEM11 | ENVS21 | ENVS23) & (CSEN20 & CSEN20L & CSEN21 & CSEN21L & MATH122 & CSCI161 & CSCI163 & CSEN177 & CSEN177L)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: At least four required upper‑division courses must be taken at SCU.

otherNotes: Students should decide their emphasis by the end of junior year; only one emphasis allowed.
Data Science may not be used as an emphasis for both majors.
Recommended to take additional upper‑division courses beyond the minimum requirements.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Substitutions for upper‑division courses may be approved by the Chair.

Prepared for the CSET.

emphases.name: Individual

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Courses must be approved by the advisor at least three quarters before graduation; at least three of the five must be CSCI or MATH; CSEN178 recommended does not count.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Modern Languages and Literatures
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Modern Languages and Literatures prepares students to communicate effectively across cultures and appreciate cultural diversity through rigorous language and culture curricula in Arabic, Chinese, French, German, Italian, Japanese, and Spanish. We offer BA degrees in French and Francophone studies, Italian studies, and Spanish studies, with honors available for French majors, and minors in French and Francophone studies, Italian studies, Japanese studies, and Spanish studies.

majors.name: French and Francophone Studies
majors.description: A Bachelor of Arts in French and Francophone Studies emphasizing advanced language proficiency, cultural and literary analysis, and global citizenship.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (FREN100 & FREN101)

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Upper‑division French and Francophone studies units

otherNotes: At least one course in French and Francophone literatures is required.
Honors programs are available for French majors.

majors.name: Italian Studies
majors.description: A Bachelor of Arts in Italian Studies focusing on advanced language, literature, and culture of the Italian‑speaking world.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ITAL100 & ITAL101)

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Upper‑division Italian language, literature, and culture units

majors.name: Spanish Studies
majors.description: A Bachelor of Arts in Spanish Studies requiring advanced Spanish language proficiency, literature and culture studies, and elective Spanish coursework.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Courses in specified categories must not duplicate earlier requirements

minors.name: French and Francophone Studies
minors.description: A minor in French and Francophone Studies for advanced language competence and cultural literacy.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (FREN100 & FREN101)

unitRequirements.requirementDescription: Upper‑division French and Francophone studies units

otherNotes: At least one course in French and Francophone literatures is required.

minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ITAL100 & ITAL101)

minors.description: A minor in Spanish Studies for enhanced Spanish language proficiency and cultural literacy.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Elective not taken to fulfill other requirements

deptsAndPrograms.name: Music
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Music offers a Bachelor of Arts in Music and a minor in Music (with a Musical Theatre minor available in conjunction with the Department of Theatre and Dance). The curriculum develops skills in theory, musicianship, performance, and music appreciation through individual study, ensemble participation, and applied instruction.

majors.name: Music
majors.description: Bachelor of Arts in Music
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (MUSC1 & MUSC2 & MUSC3 & MUSC1A & MUSC2A & MUSC3A & 2(MUSC7 | MUSC8 | MUSC9 | MUSC10) & (MUSC16 | MUSC116) & 5(MUSC100-199) & 1(MUSC114 | MUSC124 | MUSC127 | MUSC130 | MUSC131 | MUSC132 | MUSC133 | MUSC134 | MUSC135 | MUSC136 | MUSC139 | MUSC189 | MUSC190 | MUSC192 | MUSC194 | MUSC195 | MUSC196) & 1(MUSC9 | MUSC115 | MUSC119 | MUSC157))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students may take a Music Theory Placement Exam to place into an appropriate theory or musicianship course, but must still complete two courses from each sequence

deptsAndPrograms.name: Neuroscience
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Neuroscience program leading to a Bachelor of Science degree provides students with the scientific foundation needed to understand the nervous system at many levels—from molecular to patient symptomatology—using interdisciplinary approaches to examine biological, computational, and psychological underpinnings, ethical issues, and environmental factors in health, disease, and development.

majors.name: Neuroscience
majors.description: Bachelor of Science degree in Neuroscience.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Philosophy
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Philosophy offers a Bachelor of Arts in philosophy. Philosophy inquires into the relation of human beings to the world — what we are, how we know, what values are, and how we live — promoting analytical thinking and precise expression, and preparing students for careers in law, government, finance, media, writing, computer programming, and other fields.

majors.name: Philosophy
majors.description: Bachelor of Arts in philosophy, exploring human inquiry into knowledge, reality, values, and life.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: No one class may fulfill both the Non‑Western Philosophy and the History of Philosophy requirement; any PHIL 199 used as an upper‑division elective must be 5 units; the one lower‑division PHIL 40–45 requirement is waived for students who completed a Foundations Core sequence in Philosophy (PHIL 1A/2A or PHIL 11A/12A).

minors.name: Philosophy
minors.description: Minor in philosophy with foundation in history and logic plus upper‑division electives.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: To qualify as an upper‑division elective, any PHIL 199 class must be 5 units.

emphases.description: Courses preparing for legal and justice studies.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: 4(PHIL108 | PHIL110 | PHIL113 | PHIL116-129 | PHIL152 | PHIL156 | PHIL162 | PHIL185A | PHIL185B | PHIL186)

emphases.name: Ethics and Values
emphases.description: Courses in ethical theory and values analysis.

emphases.name: History of Philosophy
emphases.description: Courses in ancient, medieval, modern, and non‑Western philosophical traditions.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Physics
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Physics offers lecture and laboratory instruction leading to the Bachelor of Science in Physics (with a traditional physics track or a biophysics track), the Bachelor of Science in Engineering Physics, and an academic minor in Physics. The program provides preparation for careers in industry, government labs, secondary education, finance, entrepreneurship, and for graduate study in physics, astronomy, engineering, biophysics, environmental and geological sciences, medical physics, and related fields.

majors.name: Physics
majors.description: Provides core instruction in physics, mathematics, and chemistry with two program tracks: a traditional physics track and a biophysics track.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Political Science
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Political Science offers a Bachelor of Science in Political Science. It introduces students to the analysis of political behavior, values, institutions, and governments and prepares them for graduate and professional studies and careers in public service, research, nonprofits, and the private sector. The department also facilitates practical field experience through internships and participates in Washington, D.C., programs and international study abroad opportunities.

majors.name: Political Science
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Political Science
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: 1(MATH8 | MATH11 | MATH30 | MATH35) & (POLI1 & POLI2 & POLI25 & POLI30 & POLI99 & (POLI40 | ECON1 | ECON2)) & 7(POLI100-199)

otherRequirements.requirementName: Upper-division subfield distribution and seminar timing
otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Seven upper-division POLI courses must include one lecture course from four of the five subfields (United States politics, comparative politics, international relations, political philosophy, applied quantitative methods), two additional upper-division POLI electives (one may be a 5‑unit internship), and a senior seminar taken after achieving senior status or with instructor permission.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: ECON1 or ECON2 may not be substituted for POLI40 in the minor.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Psychology
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Psychology offers a Bachelor of Science in Psychology. Psychology is the scientific study of behavior, emotion, and thought as part of a liberal arts education. A major in psychology prepares students for careers and advanced study, including graduate work for professional practice.

majors.name: Psychology
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Psychology
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (PSYC1 & PSYC2 & PSYC51 & PSYC52 & PSYC53) & ((MATH6 & MATH8) | ((MATH35 | MATH11) & MATH8)) & 1(PSYC165 | PSYC166 | PSYC167) & 1(PSYC172 | PSYC184 | PSYC185 | PSYC196) & 1(PSYC115 | PSYC117 | PSYC134 | PSYC140 | PSYC157 | PSYC158) & 1(PSYC150 | PSYC160 | PSYC162) & 1(PSYC120 | PSYC130 | PSYC131 | PSYC138) & 1(PSYC111 | PSYC116 | PSYC118 | PSYC132 | PSYC133 | PSYC141 | PSYC151 | PSYC154 | PSYC168 | PSYC175 | PSYC178 | PSYC199A) & 3(PSYC100-199)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: In addition to PSYC courses, students must fulfill the university undergraduate Core Curriculum requirements for the Bachelor of Science degree.

otherNotes: Majors may pursue Honors in Psychology by maintaining a 3.3 GPA in psychology courses, completing PSYC 99 and a senior project approved by the faculty honors committee; honors students are expected to participate in department-sponsored events.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Public Health
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Public Health offers a B.S. in Public Health Science, a minor in Public Health, and manages the Global Health Pathway of the University Core. The major is interdisciplinary, exploring structural, social, environmental, and biological influences on health through required and elective coursework, a capstone, and a 100‑hour internship.

majors.name: Public Health Science
majors.description: An interdisciplinary program focused on population and individual health through structural, social, environmental, and biological perspectives, culminating in a senior capstone and internship.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students must complete at least 100 hours of public health‑related internship work, approved in advance by a Department of Public Health faculty member. Internships may be part‑time or full‑time, during the academic year or summer; course credit for volunteer internships is available.

minors.name: Public Health
minors.description: An interdisciplinary minor introducing core public health concepts, scientific foundations, social science and statistical methods, and upper‑division topics on factors influencing health.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (PHSC150 & (PHSC1 | PHSC2 | PHSC3) & 2((PHSC1-199) & !(PHSC1 | PHSC2 | PHSC3 | PHSC150)) & (MATH8 | ANTH112 | BIOL160 | ENVS110 | COMM110 | OMIS40 | PHSC50 | PSYC40 | SOCI120) & (BIOL1A | BIOL2))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: At least three approved upper‑division elective courses, including courses from at least two different departments.

otherNotes: Students are encouraged to study abroad and may petition the Department Chair to include new relevant courses.

emphases.name: Health Science
emphases.description: Emphasis on biomedical foundations and social science, combining core public health courses with biology, chemistry, statistics, and electives.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: (PHSC1 & PHSC2 & PHSC3 & PHSC100 & PHSC139 & PHSC150 & PHSC190 & PHSC197 & BIOL1A & BIOL1B & BIOL1C & CHEM11 & CHEM12 & CHEM31 & ((MATH35 & MATH36) | (MATH11 & MATH12)) & (PHSC50 | MATH8 | ANTH112 | BIOL160 | ENVS110 | COMM110 | OMIS40 | PSYC51 | SOCI120) & 1((PHSC1-199) & !(PHSC1 | PHSC2 | PHSC3 | PHSC100 | PHSC139 | PHSC150 | PHSC190 | PHSC197 | PHSC50)))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Two approved introductory social science courses; two approved upper‑division biomedical electives (at least one with a lab); two approved upper‑division social science or humanities electives; and an approved 100‑hour internship.

otherNotes: Students are encouraged to study abroad.

emphases.name: Health and Society
emphases.description: Emphasis on social, cultural, economic, and historical determinants of health through core public health courses, social sciences, and electives.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: (PHSC1 & PHSC2 & PHSC3 & PHSC50 & PHSC100 & PHSC125 & PHSC139 & PHSC150 & PHSC175 & PHSC190 & PHSC197 & (BIOL2 | BIOL1A | BIOL11) & (MATH35 | MATH11) & 1((PHSC1-199) & !(PHSC1 | PHSC2 | PHSC3 | PHSC50 | PHSC100 | PHSC125 | PHSC139 | PHSC150 | PHSC175 | PHSC190 | PHSC197)))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Six approved introductory social science courses from two departments; three approved upper‑division social science electives; and an approved 100‑hour internship.

otherNotes: Students are encouraged to study abroad.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Religious Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Religious Studies offers a Bachelor of Arts in Religious Studies and a minor in Religious Studies. In keeping with the University’s Catholic and Jesuit liberal‑education traditions, the department provides courses in Scripture, Catholic theology, ethics, and spirituality, as well as broad offerings in other religious traditions and methodological approaches. Courses are organized in three areas: Theology, Ethics, and Spirituality (TESP); Scripture and Tradition (SCTR); and Religion and Society (RSOC).

majors.name: Religious Studies
majors.description: The Bachelor of Arts in Religious Studies provides foundational study in three areas of religion—Scripture and Tradition, Theology, Ethics and Spirituality, and Religion and Society—through a combination of lower‑ and upper‑division courses.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: 3(SCTR1-99 | TESP1-99 | RSOC1-99) & 8(SCTR100-199 | TESP100-199 | RSOC100-199 | RELS190) & 1(SCTR111 | SCTR111R | SCTR128 | TESP119 | TESP119R | TESP124 | TESP124R | TESP131 | WGST149 | TESP131R | WGST149R | TESP141 | TESP152 | TESP185 | TESP185R | TESP196 | TESP196R)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Four of the eight upper‑division courses must be seminars—one seminar in each area (RSOC, SCTR, TESP) plus RELS 190 Seminar in Interreligious Dialogue.

minors.name: Religious Studies
minors.description: The minor in Religious Studies provides introductory, intermediate, and advanced coursework across the department’s three areas, with at least one course from each area.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: 1(SCTR1-19 | TESP1-19 | RSOC1-19) & 2(SCTR20-99 | TESP20-99 | RSOC20-99) & 4(SCTR100-199 | TESP100-199 | RSOC100-199 | RELS190) & 7@{min_unique_depts:3}(SCTR1-199 | TESP1-199 | RSOC1-199 | RELS190)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: One of the four advanced‑level courses must be a Religious Studies seminar.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Sociology
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Sociology equips students to engage in positive social change to transform the world around them. Sociology at SCU capitalizes on the diversity of research methods and approaches that prepare students to pursue a range of professional opportunities and/or enter a number of fields of graduate study. SCU Sociology awakens the “sociological imagination” in each of us and our collective ability to play a role in shaping both our own lives and the society we share at home and in the world around us. Students may also choose to concentrate in one or more Concentrations in the major. See the department website for more information.

majors.name: Sociology
majors.description: The sociology major provides foundational and advanced study of social structures, processes, and change, preparing students for professional careers or graduate study.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: SOCI1 & SOCI35 & SOCI118 & SOCI119 & SOCI120 & SOCI198 & (SOCI121 | SOCI122) & (8(SOCI100-199) | (7(SOCI100-199) & 1(SOCI30 | SOCI33 | SOCI49 | SOCI60 | SOCI65 | SOCI91 | SOCI99)))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: In addition to these requirements, students must fulfill the undergraduate Core Curriculum for the Bachelor of Science degree.

minors.name: Sociology
minors.description: The sociology minor offers foundational coursework and electives to complement major studies or broaden academic interests.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: SOCI1 & SOCI35 & SOCI119 & ((1(SOCI30 | SOCI33 | SOCI49 | SOCI60 | SOCI65 | SOCI91 | SOCI99) & 3(SOCI100-199)) | 4(SOCI100-199))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students must also fulfill any applicable university core requirements.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Theatre and Dance
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Theatre and Dance offers a BA in Theatre Arts with emphases in Theatre or Dance, and minors in Theatre, Dance, Theatre Design and Technology, and Musical Theatre. The program emphasizes academic rigor, artistic discipline, creative expression, faculty mentorship, and extensive performance opportunities.

majors.name: Theatre Arts
majors.description: Bachelor of Arts in Theatre Arts requiring completion of core department courses plus an emphasis in Theatre or Dance and a senior project.

minors.name: Theatre
minors.description: Minor in Theatre provides foundational courses in theatre performance and production.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (THTR10 & (THTR8 | THTR24) & THTR30 & (THTR41 | THTR42) & 4(THTR100-199 | DANC100-199) & (THTR39 | THTR139))

minors.name: Dance
minors.description: Minor in Dance provides foundational courses in dance technique, history, and performance.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: One course each in ballet and jazz (one at Level III)

minors.name: Theatre Design and Technology
minors.description: Minor in Theatre Design and Technology focuses on design and technical aspects of theatre production.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: 4 units of THTR 39/139, or THTR 38 plus 2 units of THTR 39/139 with a makeup production element

minors.name: Musical Theatre
minors.description: An interdisciplinary minor offered in collaboration with the Department of Music.

emphases.name: Theatre
emphases.description: Focuses on acting, design, theatre history/performance studies, dramatic literature, technical production, directing, and playwriting; culminates in a senior project demonstrating proficiency in a chosen area.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: (THTR8 & THTR9 & THTR10 & THTR30 & (THTR31 | THTR32 | THTR33) & (DANC40 | DANC43 | DANC46) & THTR41 & THTR42 & (THTR112 | THTR113 | THTR119 | THTR151 | THTR161 | THTR163 | THTR165 | THTR167) & (DANC159 | DANC189) & THTR185 & 3(THTR100-199 | DANC100-199) & (THTR39 | THTR139) & (THTR192 | THTR193 | THTR195 | THTR196 | THTR197))
otherNotes: Senior Project capstone requiring public presentation, reflection on process, assessment of department learning goals, and a culminating oral presentation.

emphases.name: Dance
emphases.description: Emphasis in modern/contemporary dance, choreography, dance history, with additional training in ballet, jazz, hip‑hop, and global dance forms; culminates in a senior project.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: One course each in ballet and jazz (one at Level III)

otherNotes: Senior Project capstone requiring public presentation, reflection on process, assessment of department learning goals, and a culminating oral presentation.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Arabic, Islamic, and Middle Eastern Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The interdisciplinary minor provides an introduction to the peoples, cultures, politics, religions, and societies of the broader Middle East and North Africa, including diasporic communities. Students engage across multiple disciplines—anthropology, art history, literary criticism, history, political science, religious studies—to develop informed engagement with contemporary issues and prepare for careers in international service, business, or advanced study.

minors.name: Arabic, Islamic, and Middle Eastern Studies
minors.description: An interdisciplinary minor requiring nine courses—six culture courses and three Arabic language courses—across at least three departments, with limits on courses from any one department.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: 6@{min_unique_depts: 3, max_courses_from_one_dept: 3}(4(ANTH156 | ANTH187 | ANTH188 | ARTH121 | ARTH164 | HIST120 | HIST144S | ARAB137 | ARAB171 | ARAB185 | ARAB199 | FREN114 | FREN173 | POLI139 | POLI142 | POLI192 | POLI196 | RSOC126 | RSOC174 | RSOC182 | RSOC190) & 2(ARTH24 | ETHN80 | ARAB1 | ARAB2 | ARAB3 | ARAB21 | ARAB22 | ARAB23 | ARAB50 | RSOC7 | RSOC67 | RSOC81 | SCTR19 | SCTR48 | TESP88))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Arabic Language: Three quarters of Arabic are required; students with prior knowledge may take a proficiency test. Department Credit Limit: No more than two courses may be counted for AIMES credit from the student’s major department.

otherNotes: In lieu of one of the six required culture courses, students may undertake an independent study/reading project with the AIMES Faculty Advisory Council (Senior Project).
Students are strongly encouraged to participate in SCU‑approved study abroad programs in Arabic, Islamic, or Middle Eastern studies.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Asian Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Asian Studies minor is designed to provide an introduction to the cultures and languages of Asia. Courses in several disciplines enable students to sample different dimensions of Asian cultures, as well as focus on a specific area of interest.

minors.name: Asian Studies
minors.description: The Asian Studies minor is designed to provide an introduction to the cultures and languages of Asia. Courses in several disciplines enable students to sample different dimensions of Asian cultures, as well as focus on a specific area of interest.
