deptsAndPrograms.name: Biotechnology
deptsAndPrograms.description: The interdisciplinary minor provides scientific background of biotechnology, explores its future potential, and offers practical laboratory experience in biotechnology research and applications. It is designed for students planning careers in the biotechnology industry or advanced degrees in molecular biology, cell biology, or biochemistry. Completion involves coursework across biology and chemistry and a research internship.

minors.name: Biotechnology
minors.description: Designed for students interested in the scientific foundations, ethical issues, laboratory skills, and applications of biotechnology.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (BIOL1A & BIOL1B & BIOL1C & BIOL175 & CHEM11 & CHEM12 & CHEM31 & CHEM32 & CHEM33 & BIOL171 & BIOL189 & 1(BIOL170 | BIOL176 | BIOL177 | BIOL191 | CHEM143) & 1(BIOL110 | BIOL111 | BIOL112 | BIOL113 | BIOL116 | BIOL122 | BIOL123 | BIOL145 | BIOL160 | BIOL172 | BIOL174 | BIOL178 | BIOL179 | CHEM141))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Complete a research internship (minimum 10 weeks full-time or 300–400 hours part-time) in a biotechnology setting, approved in advance by the director, and submit a written project report for evaluation.

otherNotes: BIOL171 and BIOL189 should be taken concurrently.
If BIOL171 or BIOL189 is not offered, any SCU course focused on medical ethics may be used as a replacement with director approval.
Strongly recommended (data analysis/computational): BIOL 160, 170, 172, and 178.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Catholic Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: An interdisciplinary minor open to students from all departments for the study of the intellectual tradition of the Catholic faith. It emphasizes intensive study of Catholicism across cultures, critical engagement with contemporary thought, and assigns each student a faculty mentor. The program, in partnership with the Ignatian Center for Jesuit Education, offers intellectual, cultural, social, and religious opportunities.

minors.name: Catholic Studies
minors.description: An interdisciplinary minor open to students from all departments for the study of the intellectual tradition of the Catholic faith. It emphasizes intensive study of Catholicism across cultures, critical engagement with contemporary thought, and assigns each student a faculty mentor. The program, in partnership with the Ignatian Center for Jesuit Education, offers intellectual, cultural, social, and religious opportunities.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Two courses in Catholic theology from offerings in the Department of Religious Studies

deptsAndPrograms.name: Gerontology
deptsAndPrograms.description: Gerontology is an interdisciplinary field focused on the study of older adults, typically defined as over age 65. Students in this minor gain hands‑on experience working with and for older adults in the community and engage with intersections of diverse experiences.

minors.name: Gerontology
minors.description: An interdisciplinary minor examining aging processes, health, mental health, and discrimination across diverse groups, with experiential learning.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: 1(ANTH1-99 | PSYC1-99 | PHSC1-99 | SOCI1-99) & ANTH172 & PSYC196 & GERO198

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: No more than two courses may be counted from any one discipline.

otherNotes: Two courses that provide opportunities to apply course content to age‑related issues from disciplines including anthropology, biology, psychology, religious studies, and sociology.

deptsAndPrograms.name: International Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The International Studies Minor enables students to study global issues or focus on a geographic area through an interdisciplinary lens. It provides a framework for adding a global dimension to a major or preparing for careers in diverse intercultural teams.

minors.name: International Studies
minors.description: Students complete four foundation courses, three emphasis courses (Global Thematic or Area Studies), and a capstone experience abroad or equivalent.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: 2(ANTH3 | ANTH50 | ANTH156 | ANTH159 | COMM2 | COMM107A | COMM162B | ECON3 | ECON181 | ECON182 | POLI2 | POLI25 | POLI121 | POLI132 | SOCI133 | SOCI134 | SOCI137) & 2(MODL100-199)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: At least one of the two social science foundation courses must be chosen from those indicated with “*.”

otherNotes: Upper-division modern language requirement may be met by placement examination through the Modern Languages Department.

Capstone Course: A minimum of 20 contact hours in a class, academic internship, or community‑based learning experience abroad with academic oversight and assessment; may be fulfilled by one quarter of study abroad related to the chosen emphasis or an approved alternative.

emphases.name: Global Thematic Emphasis
emphases.description: Three courses addressing an international issue that transcends a single nation or region, such as global health, sustainability, human rights, or diplomacy.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: 3(ANTH4 | ANTH160 | ANTH180 | COMM2 | COMM105A | ENGL153 | ENGL154 | PHSC103)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: At least two of the three courses must be upper‑division; no more than one may be in the student’s academic major.

emphases.name: Area Studies Emphasis
emphases.description: Three courses focused on a selected geographic area (Africa, Europe, or Latin America) offering an interdisciplinary introduction to the region’s cultures, languages, politics, and global challenges.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: 3(ECON130 | ECON134 | ECON135 | ENGL35 | ENGL36 | ENGL130 | ENGL136 | ENVS149 | ANTH50 | ANTH157 | ANTH164 | ANTH165 | ANTH166 | FREN108 | FREN110 | FREN111 | FREN112 | FREN113 | FREN114 | FREN117 | FREN120 | FREN130 | FREN140 | FREN150 | FREN160 | FREN161 | FREN170 | FREN171 | FREN172 | FREN173 | FREN175 | FREN183 | FREN184 | FREN185 | HIST12A | HIST64 | HIST85 | HIST91 | HIST104 | HIST140 | HIST141 | HIST142 | HIST149 | HIST157 | HIST161 | HIST162 | HIST163 | HIST164S | HIST166 | HIST169 | HIST193S | HIST196S | POLI118 | POLI119 | POLI119L | POLI132 | POLI134 | POLI136 | POLI137 | POLI140 | POLI144 | POLI145 | POLI146 | POLI149 | POLI196 | RSOC19 | RSOC46 | RSOC81 | RSOC170 | RSOC191 | SOCI133 | SOCI135 | SPAN22 | SPAN112 | SPAN113 | SPAN125 | SPAN130 | SPAN131 | SPAN132 | SPAN135 | SPAN137 | SPAN139 | SPAN140 | SPAN141 | SPAN145 | SPAN147 | SPAN148 | SPAN149 | SPAN150 | SPAN151 | SPAN156 | TESP59 | TESP184 | ARTH11A | CLAS19 | GERM110 | GERM111 | GERM112 | GERM113 | GERM115 | GERM130 | GERM140 | GERM141 | GERM150 | GERM151 | GERM160 | GERM174 | GERM183 | INTL110 | ITAL12A | ITAL110 | ITAL111 | ITAL113 | ITAL120 | ITAL121 | ITAL125 | ITAL180 | ITAL182 | ITAL183 | MUSC139 | PHIL123 | PHIL133 | PHIL137 | PHIL145)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: At least two of the three courses must be upper‑division; no more than one may be in the student’s academic major and all must correspond to the chosen region (Africa, Europe, or Latin America).

deptsAndPrograms.name: Latin American Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The interdisciplinary minor in Latin American Studies (LAS) provides students with a broad understanding of the cultures, societies, history, and diasporic connections of Latin America. Students develop global competence, cross‑cultural awareness, appreciation of social diversity and inclusion, and an understanding of links between Latin America and Latin American immigrant communities. The minor prepares students for careers in business, government, public service, international marketing, law, and nonprofit organizations, and serves as a foundation for graduate work in Anthropology, History, Political Science, Sociology, and other cultural or regional studies.

minors.name: Latin American Studies
minors.description: Through the study of cultures, societies, and history of the Latin American region and Latin diaspora, this interdisciplinary minor helps students develop global competence, cross‑cultural awareness and communication, appreciation of social diversity and inclusion, and understanding of connections between Latin America and its diasporas. Requires demonstrated competence in one language spoken in Latin America, two foundational courses, four electives on Latin America, and one course on Latin American diaspora.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: @{min_unique_depts:3}(1(ANTH185 | ANTH186 | ARTH11 | ARTH25 | HIST166 | SPAN140) & 1(HIST95 | SPAN137 | SPAN146 | SPAN147) & 4(ANTH146 | ANTH184 | ANTH185 | ANTH186 | ARTH11 | ARTH25 | ARTH152 | ENGL56 | ENGL156H | ENVS141 | ENVS144 | ENVS146 | HIST95 | HIST112 | HIST161 | HIST162 | HIST166 | HIST169 | HIST196S | SPAN112 | SPAN112EN | SPAN113 | SPAN114 | SPAN132 | SPAN135 | SPAN136 | SPAN137 | SPAN139 | SPAN142 | SPAN143 | SPAN146 | SPAN147 | POLI136 | POLI137 | POLI147 | PHSC170 | RSOC33 | RSOC91 | RSOC136 | RSOC139 | TESP60 | TESP65 | TESP109 | TESP165 | SOCI134 | SOCI135 | SOCI137) & 1(ENGL36 | ENGL136 | ENGL137 | ETHN20 | ETHN112 | ETHN120 | ETHN121 | ETHN122 | ETHN125 | ETHN126 | ETHN165 | ETHN186 | RSOC12 | RSOC139 | SOCI150 | SOCI180 | SPAN176 | TESP59 | TESP60 | TESP65 | TESP114 | THTR14))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Successful completion of an upper‑division SPAN course (level 100+) or equivalent Spanish/Portuguese proficiency exam, or one upper‑division course in Latin American literature and culture taught in Spanish. Only courses dealing with Latin America count toward the seven‑course requirement.

otherNotes: Substantial credit from study abroad or relevant immersion experiences may be approved for course credit by the LAS directors.
In lieu of one elective, juniors and seniors may design an independent study with program‑director approval.
Students are strongly encouraged to focus on Latin American/Latino peoples and cultures for the experiential learning requirement in the Core Curriculum.
Students are encouraged to participate in study abroad programs in Latin America; courses taken abroad may be credited toward minor requirements.
Students should meet with the LAS program director before enrolling in Latin American study abroad programs.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Medical and Health Humanities
deptsAndPrograms.description: Students in the Medical and Health Humanities minor apply the breadth of the Humanities to key questions and problems that define medicine and health. By exploring the history of medicine, narratives about sickness and health, religious and philosophical beliefs about disease and wellness, and the ethics of health care, students develop a deeper understanding of both the practices of medicine and health sciences as well as the experiences of illness and disability across cultures. Courses emphasize humanistic skills that graduate health and medical programs prize. This minor is open to students majoring in any discipline.

minors.name: Medical and Health Humanities
minors.description: Students in the Medical and Health Humanities minor apply the breadth of the Humanities to key questions and problems that define medicine and health. By exploring the history of medicine, narratives about sickness and health, religious and philosophical beliefs about disease and wellness, and the ethics of health care, students develop a deeper understanding of both the practices of medicine and health sciences as well as the experiences of illness and disability across cultures. Courses emphasize humanistic skills that graduate health and medical programs prize. This minor is open to students majoring in any discipline.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: 7@{max_courses_from_one_dept:3}(ANTH134 | ANTH135 | PHSC135 | CLAS41 | CLAS173 | COMM114 | WGST105A | COMM115G | WGST140 | HIST11H | HIST12H | HIST24 | HIST124 | WGST140A | HIST123 | HIST129 | HIST133 | WGST137 | SPAN21S | SPAN101S | PHIL27A | PHIL32 | PHIL113 | PHIL117 | RSOC114 | TESP141)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: No more than three courses can be taken in the same department.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Musical Theatre
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Musical Theatre Minor provides interdisciplinary training in music theory and aural skills, private voice instruction, acting, dance technique, and musical theatre history, preparing students for performance careers, teaching, or graduate study.

minors.name: Musical Theatre
minors.description: The Musical Theatre Minor offers experience and training in music, theatre, and dance, as well as musical theatre history. Objectives include proficiency in performance and audition techniques, acting, singing, dance, and knowledge of the cultural history of musical theatre.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (MUSC1 & MUSC1A & MUSC34 & (THTR8 | THTR10 | THTR24) & (DANC55 | DANC155) & 2(THTR123 | THTR165 | THTR80 | THTR180 | MUSC53 | MUSC153))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Placement tests may be taken to determine if a higher level is appropriate for Music Theory, Aural Skills, or private voice instruction requirements.

otherNotes: If placement test determines higher proficiency, an additional three quarters of on‑campus private voice instruction may be substituted for the MUSC 34 requirement.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Health Professions Advising
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Santa Clara University Health Professions Advising Program advises, mentors, supports, and educates students preparing for healthcare careers (e.g., medicine, dentistry, pharmacy, physical therapy, optometry). It provides guidance based on national acceptance data and best practices, offers individualized professional and peer advising, and equips students with resources, experiential opportunities, and networking for successful entry into health professions.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Pre-Law
deptsAndPrograms.description: Pre‑Law Advising at Santa Clara University offers guidance for undergraduates considering a legal career. Students work with designated pre‑law advisors to assess fit for law school, plan preparation (including LSAT study), and develop a curriculum that strengthens analytical, research, and communication skills. There is no required major; applicants come from diverse fields. Advisors help select courses to deepen reading comprehension and logical reasoning. Suggested electives span departments such as Business, Communication, Economics, English, Environmental Studies, Ethnic Studies, Experiential Learning for Social Justice, Finance, Management, Philosophy, Political Science, Sociology, Theatre and Dance, and Women’s and Gender Studies.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Premodern Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The minor in Premodern Studies offers a cross‑disciplinary, global study of the premodern period (late antiquity to 1800), examining how premodern people, events, and institutions helped shape the modern world. Completion is noted on the transcript with a certificate.

minors.name: Premodern Studies
minors.description: Students complete seven courses drawn from the premodern offerings across the curriculum, ensuring breadth and depth in lower‑ and upper‑division work.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: 7@{min_unique_depts:3}(ANTH146 | ANTH148 | ANTH184 | ANTH185 | ARTH21 | ARTH22 | ARTH23 | ARTH25 | ARTH114 | ARTH120 | ARTH121 | ARTH123 | ARTH144 | ARTH165 | ARTH166 | ARTH167 | CLAS51 | CLAS52 | CLAS135 | CLAS144 | ENGL41 | ENGL54 | ENGL119 | ENGL131 | ENGL141 | ENGL143 | ENGL144 | ENGL144G | ENGL151A | ENGL151B | ENGL151C | HIST30 | HIST43 | HIST143 | HIST70 | HIST170 | HIST75 | HIST175 | HIST91 | HIST94 | HIST96A | HIST97 | HIST104 | HIST117 | HIST118 | HIST120 | HIST123 | HIST126 | HIST130A | HIST146A | HIST147A | HIST152 | HIST166 | HIST186 | FREN115 | FREN150 | FREN182 | GERM140 | ITAL120 | SPAN130 | SPAN165 | MUSC42 | MUSC142 | MUSC43 | MUSC143 | MUSC189 | MUSC190 | MUSC192 | PHIL14 | PHIL15 | PHIL124 | PHIL125 | PHIL142 | PHIL155 | PHIL178 | PHIL179 | SCTR19 | SCTR112 | SCTR157 | SCTR175 | RSOC7 | RSOC81 | TESP71 | TESP79 | TESP82 | TESP143 | TESP183 | TESP190 | THTR116 | THTR117 | THTR118 | THTR119 | THTR120 | WGST48 | WGST141A | WGST153 | WGST176)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: No more than three lower‑division courses may count toward the minor.

otherNotes: One upper‑division course must include an interdisciplinary research paper based on source materials and secondary works; this may be fulfilled by enrolling in a 199 independent study under faculty supervision.

Certain sections of Cultures & Ideas 11A and 12A, special topics, directed reading/research, and seminar courses in premodern topics may apply; students should consult the program director to determine applicability.
Study of French, German, Greek, Italian, Latin, and/or Spanish is strongly recommended but not required; consult with the program director to select an appropriate cluster.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Pre-Teaching
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Pre‑Teaching program in the School of Education and Counseling Psychology provides guidance and preparation for students seeking California multiple‑subject and single‑subject teaching credentials. It outlines recommended undergraduate preparations (including majors in areas such as psychology, child studies, sociology, or any other major plus participation in the urban education minor), credential requirements (bachelor’s degree, U.S. Constitution requirement, basic skills demonstration, CSET or subject‑matter program, field experience, and for multiple‑subject candidates the RICA exam), and describes the combined Master of Arts in Teaching and Teaching Credential (MATTC) fifth‑year program. It also highlights the Future Teachers Project (FTP) that supports underrepresented students entering teaching.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Sustainability
deptsAndPrograms.description: The sustainability minor helps students discover the connections and balance among a healthy environment, just societies, and a vibrant economy that meet all people’s fundamental needs currently and in the future, especially those of the global poor. Courses explore the environmental, societal, and economic aspects of sustainability, and how to take action to improve sustainability.

minors.name: Sustainability
minors.description: An interdisciplinary program requiring eight courses: one foundational course, two courses each in environmental, societal, and economic dimensions, and one action learning course.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ENVS95) & 2(ANTH160 | BIOL5 | BIOL6 | BIOL134 | BIOL156 | BIOL180 | CENG20 | CENG120 | CENG122 | CENG123 | CENG124 | CENG139 | CENG140 | CENG142 | CENG143 | CENG144 | CENG160 | CENG161 | CENG162 | CHEM1 | CHEM12 | CHEM12H | CHEM101 | ENGR1 | ENGR1L | ENGR15 | ENGR60 | ENVS5 | ENVS21 | ENVS23 | ENVS180 | ENVS145 | ENVS160 | ENVS166 | ENVS167 | ENVS185 | MECH121 | PHYS120) & 2(ANTH50 | ANTH140 | ANTH154 | ANTH159 | COMM117 | COMM153 | COMM157 | COMM158 | ECON129 | ECON160 | ENGL176 | ENGR19 | ENGR110 | ENGR161 | MGMT177 | ENVS22 | ENVS128 | ENVS131 | ENVS146 | ENVS155 | ETHN156 | PHIL29 | PHIL29H | PHYS192 | POLI123 | RSOC64 | SCTR111 | SOCI33 | SOCI132 | SOCI134 | SOCI138 | TESP26 | TESP33 | TESP84 | TESP152) & 2(ACTG140 | BUSN70 | BUSN150 | BUSN170 | CENG128 | ECON1 | ECON101 | ECON111 | ENGR171A | ENGR173 | MGMT6 | MGMT6H | MGMT41 | MGMT80 | MGMT168 | MGMT176 | MKTG189 | OMIS108E | PHIL26 | POLI40) & 1(BUSN132 | BUSN151A | COMM113B | ELSJ135 | ENGR25 | ENGR110 | ENGR125 | ENGR136 | ENVS77 | ENVS195 | MGMT42)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: No more than three courses can come from a student's major.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Urban Education
deptsAndPrograms.description: The interdisciplinary minor in Urban Education provides Santa Clara undergraduate students seeking to become elementary or secondary teachers with foundational coursework in educational theory, urban school observation and reflective experiences, U.S. constitutional history, and the sociological and psychological foundations of education, while critically examining social challenges such as poverty, crime, and prejudice that impact today’s youth and families. Recommended for students from diverse majors interested in careers working directly with children and families from multicultural backgrounds.

minors.name: Urban Education
minors.description: An interdisciplinary minor combining foundational education courses with analysis of social issues affecting urban schools and youth.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (POLI1 | HIST96A | HIST96B) & (PSYC2) & (CHST106 & CHST138) & (PSYC134) & 2(CHST104 | ENGL104 | ENGL105 | ETHN151 | ETHN157 | ETHN161 | ETHN167 | HIST184 | HIST186 | PSYC172 | PSYC185 | PSYC185EL | SOCI153 | SOCI157 | SOCI175 | PHSC131 | ENVS131)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Only two courses in a student’s major can be used to fulfill requirements in the Urban Education minor.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Accounting
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Accounting strives to provide high-quality accounting instruction, conduct research that contributes to the understanding of accounting issues, and provide superior service to students and alumni, the profession, the University, and the business community. It offers a major in Accounting and a joint major in Accounting and Information Systems, the latter having a STEM designation effective September 2023.

majors.name: Accounting
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Commerce major in Accounting.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ACTG120 & ACTG130 & ACTG131 & ACTG132 & ACTG134 & ACTG135 & ACTG136 & ACTG138)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: In addition to fulfilling undergraduate Core Curriculum and Leavey School of Business requirements for the bachelor of science in commerce, students must complete the departmental courses listed.

otherNotes: Accounting majors may use ACTG 134 to satisfy both the information systems requirement in the Leavey School of Business curriculum and the Science, Technology & Society requirement in the 2009 University Core.

majors.name: Accounting and Information Systems
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Commerce joint major in Accounting and Information Systems, offered by the Accounting Department and the Information Systems & Analytics Department. This major has the STEM designation.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ACTG120 & ACTG130 & ACTG131 & ACTG132 & ACTG135 & ACTG136 & ACTG138 & OMIS30 & OMIS105 & OMIS106 & ACTG155 & 1(OMIS107 | OMIS111 | OMIS113 | OMIS114 | OMIS120 | OMIS135 | OMIS137))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: In addition to fulfilling undergraduate Core Curriculum and Leavey School of Business requirements for the bachelor of science in commerce, students must complete the departmental courses listed.

otherNotes: Accounting and information systems majors may use OMIS 30 to satisfy the information systems requirement in the Leavey School of Business curriculum.
OMIS 150 is cross-listed with ACTG 155.
Accounting and information systems majors are required to enroll in ACTG 155.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Economics
deptsAndPrograms.description: Economics studies how individual and collective choices determine the use of scarce resources to produce and distribute goods and services. It provides insights into wealth and poverty, unemployment, inflation, international trade, economic growth, and market success and failure, preparing students for careers in the private and public sectors and for graduate study in economics, business, public policy, and law.

majors.name: Economics
majors.description: A bachelor of science in commerce major that builds a foundation in economic theory, quantitative methods, and real‑world applications.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ECON41 & ECON42) & (ECON113 & ECON114 & ECON115 & (ECON181 | ECON182)) & (2(ECON116-199) & 3(ECON100-199)) & (MATH12 | MATH31)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students must also fulfill undergraduate Core Curriculum and Leavey School of Business requirements for the bachelor of science in commerce degree.

otherNotes: Students are encouraged to plan early with an advisor if considering graduate study in economics, business, public policy, or law.
Prerequisites: A grade of C- or better in ECON 1, 2, and 3 is required for all upper-division economics courses.

minors.name: Economics
minors.description: A College of Arts and Sciences minor providing foundational study in economics with both introductory and upper-division courses and a mathematics prerequisite.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (ECON1 & ECON2 & ECON3 & ECON113 & ECON115) & 2(ECON100-199) & (MATH11 | MATH30)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students must satisfy any general College of Arts and Sciences requirements for a minor.

emphases.name: Data Analysis for Economics
emphases.description: Provides structured coursework in econometrics and data analysis applied to economics.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: ECON43 & (ECON173 | ECON174) & 3(ECON134 | ECON135 | ECON142 | ECON150 | ECON151 | ECON154 | ECON166 | ECON186 | ECON187 | ECON188 | ECON173 | ECON174)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: All courses in the concentration must be passed with a grade of C or higher.

otherNotes: All upper-division concentration courses count toward the three upper-division electives in the economics major.

One course in list C may be substituted, with approval, by an approved non‑economics course or independent study with a significant data analysis component; pre-approved substitutions: CSCI 183, ENVS 117, OMIS 114, OMIS 150.
Non‑economics substitutions do not count as economics major electives.

emphases.name: Mathematical Economics
emphases.description: Designed for students seeking a rigorous, math‑focused approach to economic theory.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: (MATH11 & MATH12 & MATH13 & MATH14 & MATH53 & AMTH106) & 3(ECON170 | ECON171 | ECON172 | ECON173 | ECON174 | ECON187 | ECON188)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students completing this concentration take MATH 11 and MATH 12 instead of MATH 30 and MATH 31.

otherNotes: MATH 122 and MATH 123 are strongly recommended.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Finance
deptsAndPrograms.description: Finance is at the center of well‑managed businesses, from high‑technology companies to mutual fund companies. The program develops knowledge and managerial skills in corporate and investment settings. Graduates pursue careers as corporate financial officers, traders, investment managers, financial analysts, financial planners, investment bankers, stockbrokers, regulators, and other specialties.

majors.name: Finance
majors.description: Bachelor of Science in Commerce with a major in Finance.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: FNCE124 & FNCE125 & (MATH12 | MATH31 | FNCE186) & 4((FNCE100-199) & !(FNCE118 | FNCE127 | FNCE129 | FNCE131))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Courses FNCE 118, FNCE 127, FNCE 129, and FNCE 131 do not satisfy upper‑division elective requirements for finance majors and are not included in the finance major GPA.

minors.name: Real Estate
minors.description: The Real Estate minor requires core real estate courses plus a set of electives drawn from primary and secondary lists, with different elective loads depending on student status.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: FNCE118 & (FNCE127 | FNCE129)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Business School students must complete 3 electives from the Primary Elective List; non‑Business School students must complete 4 electives (3 if they have completed BUSN 70 or BUSN 170, ACTG 11 or ACTG 11A, and FNCE 121). Primary Elective List: FNCE 127, FNCE 129, FNCE 128, FNCE 131, ECON 156, ENVS 116, ENVS 128, CENG 118, CENG 119. Secondary Elective List (at most one): CENG 128, FNCE 143, OMIS 114, OMIS 115, OMIS 116, OMIS 118, MKTG 189. Students who take both FNCE 127 & FNCE 129 may use the second toward the elective requirement.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Management and Entrepreneurship
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Management and Entrepreneurship curriculum emphasizes rigorous analysis and managerial application. Courses are offered in organizational behavior, human resource management, team dynamics, leadership, sustainability, negotiations, strategic management, business ethics, entrepreneurship, new venture creation, and international management to provide an overall leadership perspective.

majors.name: Management
majors.description: As a management major, students learn to analyze complex business problems within organizational environments and apply appropriate strategies to solve them. They develop ethical reasoning, interpersonal competencies, leadership skills, and effective communication, teamwork, and group dynamics abilities.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (MGMT174 & 4(MGMT110 | MGMT164 | MGMT165 | MGMT166 | MGMT168 | MGMT169 | MGMT170 | MGMT171 | MGMT172 | MGMT173 | MGMT175 | MGMT176 | MGMT177 | MGMT178 | MGMT179 | MGMT180 | MGMT181 | MGMT197 | MGMT198 | MGMT198E | MGMT199))
otherNotes: Majors often enrich their academic experience by selecting a minor in entrepreneurship or international business, as well as directed studies practicums and internships.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Marketing
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Marketing department develops students’ decision-making and managerial skills in innovation, high technology, retailing, digital marketing, customer analysis, and strategic marketing to prepare them for careers in general management, advertising, retailing, sales, brand management, and market research.

majors.name: Marketing
majors.description: The Marketing major requires core marketing courses and electives to build a foundation in marketing strategy, customer and competitive analysis, and digital and retail marketing.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (BUSN179 & MKTG179 & MKTG182 & MKTG183 & 3(MKTG165 | MKTG175 | MKTG177 | MKTG178 | MKTG185 | MKTG186 | MKTG187 | MKTG188 | MKTG189 | MKTG190 | MKTG191 | MKTG192 | MKTG194))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: MKTG198 cannot be substituted for an elective course in the major.

minors.name: Marketing
minors.description: The Marketing minor provides a foundation in customer‑centered strategy through a core principles course and electives to deepen strategic, creative, and analytical decision‑making skills.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (MKTG181 & 4(MKTG165 | MKTG175 | MKTG177 | MKTG178 | MKTG185 | MKTG186 | MKTG187 | MKTG188 | MKTG189 | MKTG190 | MKTG191 | MKTG192 | MKTG194))

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: MKTG165 will not count towards the required electives in the Marketing minor if also pursuing a Retail Studies minor.

otherNotes: Minor open only to Business students with Junior standing via online application; limited enrollment.

emphases.name: Business and Technology
emphases.description: Recommended courses for students interested in Business and Technology Marketing.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: 3(MKTG175 | MKTG177 | MKTG185 | MKTG187 | MKTG186 | MKTG188 | MKTG189 | MKTG190 | MKTG191 | MKTG194)

emphases.name: Consumer and Channel
emphases.description: Recommended courses for students interested in Consumer and Channel Marketing.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: 3(MKTG165 | MKTG175 | MKTG186 | MKTG178 | MKTG187 | MKTG189 | MKTG190 | MKTG191 | MKTG194)

emphases.name: Individually Designed
emphases.description: Three courses selected with the marketing faculty advisor to create a custom emphasis.
emphases.courseRequirementsExpression: 3(MKTG165 | MKTG175 | MKTG178 | MKTG185 | MKTG186 | MKTG187 | MKTG188 | MKTG189 | MKTG190 | MKTG191)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Courses must be selected with the student’s marketing faculty advisor.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Information Systems & Analytics
deptsAndPrograms.description: Undergraduate study in ISA explores the use of computer information systems and analytical decision‑making methods in organizations, equipping students to design, implement, and evaluate systems central to an organization’s success. The department offers a Bachelor of Science in commerce with a major in Management Information Systems (MIS), an interdepartmental major in Accounting and Information Systems (AIS), an MIS minor for non‑business and non‑MIS majors, and a Business Analytics minor for business students. The MIS major and minor and the AIS major are STEM‑designated.

majors.name: Management Information Systems
majors.description: The MIS major explores computer information systems and analytical decision‑making methods in organizations, preparing students to design, implement, and evaluate systems central to business success.
majors.courseRequirementsExpression: (OMIS30 & OMIS105 & OMIS106 & OMIS107 & 3(OMIS111 | OMIS112 | OMIS113 | OMIS114 | OMIS116 | OMIS117 | OMIS118 | OMIS120 | OMIS135 | OMIS137 | OMIS150))

majors.name: Accounting and Information Systems
majors.description: The AIS major combines accounting and information systems courses to prepare students for roles that integrate financial and technical decision‑making, including preparation for the CPA exam.

minors.description: The MIS minor provides non‑business and non‑MIS majors with a deeper understanding of information systems and technology applications in organizations.

minors.description: The Business Analytics minor provides business students with coursework in analytical decision‑making methods and business analytics techniques to complement their major.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: A course cannot be double‑dipped in multiple programs; e.g., if OMIS 113 is taken as an elective for the BA minor, it cannot count toward the MIS major.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Entrepreneurship
deptsAndPrograms.description: The entrepreneurship minor provides students interested in developing a business or working in a startup the chance to explore that career option and acquire skills in venture creation, opportunity evaluation, business planning, and funding analysis. A critical element is an internship with an emerging for‑profit or social benefit organization.

minors.name: Entrepreneurship
minors.description: The entrepreneurship minor provides students interested in developing a business or working in a startup the chance to explore that career option and acquire skills in venture creation, opportunity evaluation, business planning, and funding analysis. A critical element is an internship with an emerging for‑profit or social benefit organization.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (MGMT164 & MGMT165 & MGMT198E) & 2(BUSN197 | ECON129 | ECON185 | ENVS145 | ENVS148 | FNCE141 | FNCE143 | FNCE170 | MECH144 | MGMT172 | HRNS120A | MGMT175 | MGMT177 | ENGR161 | MKTG175 | MKTG177 | MKTG182 | MKTG187 | PHSC157 | SOCI150 | SOCI172)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: The internship (MGMT 198E) must run concurrent with the course, and students cannot use past experiences toward credit in this course.

otherNotes: MGMT 164 prerequisites: MKTG 181 and ACTG 11.
MGMT 165 prerequisite: MGMT 164.
MGMT 198E pre‑ or corequisite: MGMT 165.
The minor is open via application through the Management and Entrepreneurship Department.
F‑1 international students must consult with International Students and Scholars in the Global Engagement Office prior to applying to ensure eligibility for the required internship.
Accepted business school students may begin the minor after earning 60 units; students outside the business school should ideally complete core prerequisites by the sophomore year.

deptsAndPrograms.name: International Business
deptsAndPrograms.description: The minor in international business is designed to educate students in a broad range of management and business skills in a global context. It includes coursework in language, social science, and international business and is open to all undergraduates. The minor provides understanding of the social, economic, and political context of international business, language communication skills, and business skills to be effective global managers.

minors.name: International Business
minors.description: The minor provides students with a background in foreign language, business fundamentals, global social science, and specialized international business courses to prepare them for management roles in a global marketplace.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: 1(ARAB23 | CHIN23 | FREN100 | GERM100 | ITAL100 | JAPN23 | SPAN23) & 1(BUSN70 | BUSN170) & 1(ACTG11 | ACTG11A) & (ECON1 & ECON2 & ECON3) & MGMT80 & 1(MGMT6 | PHIL26) & 2(ENVS50 | ECON129 | ECON134 | ECON138 | HIST105 | POLI50 | POLI119 | POLI121 | POLI122 | POLI136 | POLI137 | POLI140 | POLI142 | POLI144 | POLI146 | PSYC162 | SOCI138) & 2(FNCE151 | MGMT110 | MGMT170 | MKTG178 | ECON181 | ECON182)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Other eligible selected comparative politics courses may be approved by the director of the international business minor program.

otherNotes: Students may demonstrate required language competency by completing one of the listed courses or a more advanced 100 or 101 level course; other languages do not qualify.
Some courses may require prerequisites.
Some courses may be offered only once per year.
Completion of advanced language courses is recommended but not required.
Participation in study abroad programs or internships is recommended but not required.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Retail Studies
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Retail Studies minor, offered by the Retail Management Institute (RMI), is an in-depth, hands‑on program preparing students for diverse roles in the retail industry—including e‑commerce, buying, merchandising, digital marketing, supply chain management, and retail innovation. The curriculum combines foundational and advanced coursework with industry collaboration, an internship, corporate visits, conferences, and scholarship opportunities.

minors.name: Retail Studies
minors.description: The Retail Studies minor, offered by the Retail Management Institute (RMI), is an in-depth, hands‑on program preparing students for diverse roles in the retail industry—including e‑commerce, buying, merchandising, digital marketing, supply chain management, and retail innovation. The curriculum combines foundational and advanced coursework with industry collaboration, an internship, corporate visits, conferences, and scholarship opportunities.
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (BUSN70) & (ACTG11 | ACTG11A) & (COMM20 | COMM2 | BUSN179) & (OMIS15) & (OMIS40 | PSYC40 | MATH8 | MATH123 | AMTH108 | COMM110 | COMM100) & (COMM12 | COMM50 | OMIS34 | ACTG134 | SOCI49 | SOCI149) & (ECON1) & (MGMT160) & (MKTG181) & (MKTG165) & (BUSN198R) & (MKTG168) & (MKTG169)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Admission to the Retail Studies minor is at the discretion of the executive director based on criteria including a minimum GPA of 3.3, proven analytical skills, the ability to blend analytical and creative thinking, and previous exposure to retail.

otherNotes: BUSN179 is available only to business students.
Non‑business majors are encouraged to apply during their first or second year; business students must apply by January of junior year.
The program includes corporate visits to retailers, attendance at conferences, and scholarship opportunities.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Sustainable Food Systems
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Sustainable Food Systems minor provides students with an interdisciplinary introduction to global food systems and sustainability. It covers cultural aspects of food, food policies, nutrition and public health, social justice, sustainability, and opportunities for innovation and change within the food system. The minor prepares students for careers in food industry management, entrepreneurship, food policy, public health, and nutrition.

minors.name: Sustainable Food Systems
minors.description: An interdisciplinary minor exploring cultural, policy, health, and innovation aspects of sustainable food systems.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Applied Mathematics
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Applied Mathematics offers only graduate degree programs and operates in a service mode at the undergraduate level. Undergraduate courses are designed to bridge mathematical theory and engineering applications.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Bioengineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: Bioengineering applies engineering principles to biological systems and prepares students for careers in medical devices, biotechnology, biopharmaceutical industries, graduate study, or medical school.

majors.name: Bioengineering
majors.description: The major in bioengineering prepares students for careers in medical device, biotechnology and biopharmaceutical industries, graduate study, or entry into medical school.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students must choose one of three tracks (Biomolecular, Medical‑Device, Pre‑Med) with distinct Natural Science and Engineering course requirements. Technical electives also track‑specific.

minors.name: Bioengineering
minors.description: The minor in bioengineering is designed for students majoring in other disciplines or completing medical‑school prerequisites.

minors.description: Prepares students from any discipline to design and develop technologies and services for healthcare innovation.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Foundational courses, technical electives, experiential activity, and elective component each have multiple options; see department for details.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Civil, Environmental and Sustainable Engineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Civil, Environmental and Sustainable Engineering offers an undergraduate program that trains students to plan, design, construct, maintain, and rehabilitate infrastructure systems with an emphasis on sustainability, resilience, and the responsible use of resources. Graduates are prepared for professional practice or advanced study and are expected to serve ethically, engage in lifelong learning, and address environmental, economic, and societal requirements.

majors.name: Civil Engineering
majors.description: A Bachelor of Science program requiring foundational work in English, mathematics, natural sciences, and engineering, plus technical electives and a free elective, totaling at least 195 units.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Computer Science and Engineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Computer Science and Engineering offers two BS degree programs—Computer Science and Engineering, and Web Design and Engineering.  The CSE program provides a balanced core in software and hardware engineering and the mathematical foundations of computation, with electives to build on this core.  The Web Design and Engineering program combines technical computing education with courses in graphic art, communication, and sociology, preparing graduates to understand and shape the Web’s infrastructure and social impact.  Instruction and research are supported by the Engineering Computing Center and the University’s Information Technology Center.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Electrical and Computer Engineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: The Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering offers BS programs in electrical engineering and electrical and computer engineering. Faculty research and teaching cover electrical components, circuits, systems, sustainable energy and power, signal and image processing, machine learning, embedded and control systems, nanotechnology and integrated circuits, antennas, RF and communications, and information storage and transmission. The department maintains state‑of‑the‑art teaching and research laboratories supporting all facets of the curriculum.

deptsAndPrograms.name: General Engineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: The School of Engineering offers a Bachelor of Science in General Engineering, designed to provide a technical degree with individualized concentrations. The program is not intended for students pursuing professional engineering licensure, but rather prepares students for careers or graduate study in fields such as law, medicine, business, or education.

deptsAndPrograms.name: Mechanical Engineering
deptsAndPrograms.description: Mechanical Engineering applies physics, mathematics, and materials science to the design and realization of mechanical and thermal systems. The undergraduate curriculum provides a rigorous theoretical foundation coupled with hands-on laboratories and projects, emphasizing ethical, social, and entrepreneurial aspects and offering opportunities for cutting‑edge research.

minors.description: Minor in Mechanical Engineering
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: (MECH45 | MECH45L) & CENG41 & (ECEN50 | ECEN50L) & MECH10L & MECH12L & 2(MECH11 | MECH140 | MECH140R | CENG43 | CENG43L | MECH15 | MECH15L) & (MECH121 | MECH121R)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Choose one two‑course sequence: (MECH122/122L & MECH123/123L), (MECH122/122L & MECH132), (MECH114 & MECH115), or (MECH141/141L & MECH142/142L)

otherNotes: Note: Prerequisites may influence choice of technical sequence courses.

minors.name: Aerospace Engineering
minors.description: Minor in Aerospace Engineering
minors.courseRequirementsExpression: 2(MECH140 | MECH140R | CENG43 | MECH121 | MECH121R | MECH122 | MECH122L) & MECH145 & 2(MECH132 | MECH153 | MECH155 | MECH158 | MECH205 | MECH206 | MECH371 | MECH372 | MECH431)
otherNotes: All undergraduates eligible; students should consult the Mechanical Engineering Department for advising.

specialPrograms.name: Aerospace Studies (Air Force ROTC)
specialPrograms.description: Under an agreement with San Jose State University, Santa Clara students may enroll in the Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps (AFROTC) or United States Space Force program to complete coursework and leadership laboratories leading to a commission as a Second Lieutenant. The program covers Air Force organization, history, officer skills, leadership, management, national security policy, and physical fitness.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Mandatory weekly two‑hour leadership laboratory and twice‑weekly group physical conditioning for all AFROTC cadets

specialPrograms.name: Experiential Learning for Social Justice
specialPrograms.description: The Experiential Learning for Social Justice (ELSJ) component of Santa Clara’s Core Curriculum cultivates social justice awareness, civic engagement, and critical reflection through community-based learning placements, enabling students to engage constructively with marginalized or oppressed communities.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Participation in off‑campus community‑based learning (CBL) experiences is required for all listed ELSJ courses.

specialPrograms.name: LEAD Scholars Program
specialPrograms.description: The LEAD Scholars Program is designed for first-generation college students, focusing on academic success, student leadership, and community engagement. It provides academic and vocational development opportunities, holistic advising, peer mentoring, and community building through specialized courses, programs, and support networks.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a first-generation college student (parents did not graduate from a four-year college or university). Successful completion of ENGL 1A is a prerequisite for ENGL 2A.

specialPrograms.name: Military Science Program
specialPrograms.description: The Military Science Program offers ROTC courses to develop leadership and management skills for careers in the military or corporate world. Students complete a Basic Course (six lower‑division classes or a summer camp) and an Advanced Course (seven upper‑division classes) to qualify for commissioning as U.S. Army officers.
specialPrograms.courseRequirementsExpression: (6(MILS11 | MILS12 | MILS13 | MILS21 | MILS22 | MILS23) | MILS24) & (MILS131 & MILS132 & MILS133 & MILS134 & MILS141 & MILS142 & MILS143)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: At least one undergraduate course from each of five designated fields of study; prior to commissioning, at least one course in military history; weekly three‑hour leadership laboratories required; weekly lab work each quarter; two off‑campus exercises (optional for non‑scholarship Basic Course students, mandatory for Advanced Course and contracted students).

specialPrograms.name: Study Abroad and Global Programs
specialPrograms.description: Global Engagement at Santa Clara University offers students competitive, approved study abroad opportunities in summer, fall, winter, and spring terms to enhance academic and cultural experience. Programs include independent research, community‐based learning, and internships, and students work with advisors to select programs aligned with their goals. Summer programs are noncompetitive; fall, winter, and spring programs are competitive and limited to one term per undergraduate career. Students should review eligibility, conduct standards, costs, and other policies on the Global Engagement website.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students must meet eligibility, nomination, and program policies including standards of conduct, withdrawals, costs, financial aid, grading, accessibility, and ethics as detailed on the Global Engagement website.

specialPrograms.name: Summer Sessions
specialPrograms.description: The Summer Sessions Office coordinates a comprehensive schedule of undergraduate courses in most academic departments from June through September. Sessions are three, five, and ten weeks in length; content, prerequisites, and units are equivalent to fall, winter, and spring courses. The office invites students to reach their educational goals through accelerated courses and enforces policies on enrollment, attendance, course loads, withdrawals, and eligibility.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Any student not permitted to register during fall, winter, or spring quarters (e.g., disqualified, suspended) may not enroll in summer courses at SCU.

specialPrograms.name: University Honors Program
specialPrograms.description: The University Honors Program offers small, seminar‑style classes across disciplines that emphasize critical thinking, analytical rigor, and collaborative senior research. Honors students complete a series of specialized courses within the core curriculum and culminate their experience with a year‑long senior thesis.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Students entering at Level I (first‑year) complete nine Honors‑level courses: Critical Thinking and Writing I & II; Cultures and Ideas I & II; HNRS 20 (Difficult Dialogues seminar); one Core RTC (I, II, or III) Honors or Core Ethics Honors course; three UHP electives/experiences; plus a year‑long Senior Honors Thesis. Students entering at Level II (second‑year) complete six Honors‑level courses: HNRS 20; one Core RTC (I, II, or III) Honors or Core Ethics Honors course; four UHP electives/experiences; plus a year‑long Senior Honors Thesis.

courses.name: Business Leadership Skills
courses.description: Designed to continue learning from MGMT 71 by focusing on leadership skills specific to a business environment. Course integrates group discussion, selected readings, experiential learning, and reflective engagement experiences.

courses.name: Business Law
courses.description: This course provides the student with an overview of the legal system and primary substantive areas of law affecting business transactions including the law of contracts, torts, property, employment, business associations, securities, and white collar crime. Students exercise critical thinking and writing skills through the application of fundamental legal principles in the business context.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Completion of 45 units prior to enrollment

courses.name: Contemplative Leadership and Sustainability Program (CLASP)
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with opportunities to learn and rehearse contemplative leadership practices and explore the relationship between personal values, business, and sustainability. CLASP introduces students to issues of sustainability in industry, provides face-to-face encounters with professionals and companies/organizations already “doing the work” of sustainability, and immerses students in the region’s natural and social environments via daylong weekend excursions. Assignments include keeping a weekly journal, weekly readings, small and large group discussions, writing a short paper, and completing a group project.

courses.name: Feeding the World
courses.description: In this course, students examine the global system for the production and distribution of food, assess the ability of the system to satisfy the human demand for food, and evaluate the impact of the system on the natural environment. Students will employ tools from statistics, operations, and economics to describe, analyze, and forecast imbalances between food supply and food demand. Through a term project, students use their new skills to examine the food system in a developing nation experiencing chronic hunger.

courses.name: Food, Hunger, Poverty, Environment Immersion
courses.description: This course is designed to help students meet their social justice-oriented experiential learning requirements (ELSJ) while learning about issues related to food production and consumption, hunger, poverty, and the environment. The course blends short lectures, guided discussions and reflections, and an 11- to 14-day immersion in a selected country interacting with local people of diverse backgrounds for experiential active learning. Both quarters are required to participate in the immersion program.
courses.otherNotes: Both quarters are required to participate in the immersion program.

courses.name: Food, Hunger, Poverty, Environment Immersion
courses.description: This course is designed to help students meet their social justice-oriented experiential learning requirements (ELSJ) while learning about issues related to food production and consumption, hunger, poverty, and the environment. The course blends short lectures, guided discussions and reflections, and an 11- to 14-day immersion in a selected country interacting with local people of diverse backgrounds for experiential active learning. Both quarters are required to participate in the immersion program.
courses.otherNotes: Both quarters are required to participate in the immersion program.

courses.name: Contemporary Business for Nonmajors
courses.description: This course is specifically designed for upper-division (junior and senior), non-business majors who are interested in learning about business firms and their relation to both the global and local environment in which they operate. Course will use a business simulation as a key learning method, in addition to lectures and small group discussion.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Completion of 87.5 units prior to enrollment

courses.otherNotes: Not open to students who have completed BUSN70.

courses.name: Effective Communication in Business
courses.description: In this pragmatic professional development course, students will learn the following business communication skills: business writing, informal and formal presentations, networking, and personal brand. Students will produce quantitative and qualitative analyses and evaluations and create professional multimedia projects, proposals, and presentations. Students will also develop skills in formal and informal business writing and discourse (briefings, reports, emails, memos, interviews, social media, infographics, etc.).

courses.name: Effective Communication in Business
courses.description: In this pragmatic professional development course, students will learn the following business communication skills: business writing, informal and formal presentations, networking, and personal brand. Students will produce quantitative and qualitative analyses and evaluations, and create professional multimedia projects, proposals, and presentations. Students will also develop skills in formal and informal business writing and discourse (briefings, reports, emails, memos, interviews, social media, infographics, etc.).

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Enrollment restricted to students in the Leavey Scholars Program

courses.name: Global Experience Practicum
courses.description: Opportunity for business students to study global business issues in specific countries or regions around the world. The practicum includes selected readings, several special lectures on topics related to the target country or region, and an in-country learning session, typically two weeks after the end of spring quarter. Each practicum is led by a Leavey School of Business faculty member who travels with the students to the country to lead integration sessions, guide discussions, and generally enhance the student’s learning experience.

courses.name: LSB Community Fellows Seminar
courses.description: This seminar is completed in tandem with a community organization internship through the LSB Community Fellows program. Participants study the context of economic opportunity in the nonprofit/government sector, reflect on internship experiences, and develop professional skills. This course fulfills the ELSJ University Core requirement.

otherRequirements.requirementName: Leavey School of Business Community Fellow
otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a Leavey School of Business Community Fellow.

courses.name: LSB Community Fellows Seminar
courses.description: This seminar is completed in tandem with a community organization internship through the LSB Community Fellows program. Participants study the context of economic opportunity in the nonprofit/government sector, reflect on internship experiences, and develop professional skills. This course fulfills the ELSJ University Core requirement.

otherRequirements.requirementName: Leavey School of Business Community Fellow
otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a Leavey School of Business Community Fellow.

courses.name: LSB Community Fellows Seminar
courses.description: This seminar is completed in tandem with a community organization internship through the LSB Community Fellows program. Participants study the context of economic opportunity in the nonprofit/government sector, reflect on internship experiences, and develop professional skills. This course fulfills the ELSJ University Core requirement.

otherRequirements.requirementName: Leavey School of Business Community Fellow
otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a Leavey School of Business Community Fellow.

courses.name: Field Studies: NPI Small Business Improvement Project
courses.description: In this two-quarter course, students work directly with a small business in a local, economically disadvantaged neighborhood. Students conduct an analysis of the business owner’s goals, develop an action plan, and implement the plan to improve business performance. The purpose of the Neighborhood Prosperity Initiative is to provide a unique learning opportunity for undergraduate students and to contribute to the economic growth and prosperity of a local neighborhood in a sustainable, ethical, and effective way. This course fulfills the ELSJ University Core requirement.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Requires participation in community-based learning (CBL) experiences off campus.
Students must complete two consecutive quarters in winter and spring.

courses.name: LSB Peer Advising Practicum
courses.description: A practicum experience for Leavey School of Business Peer Advisors, which provides the opportunity to learn, apply, and integrate training and experience to provide prescriptive advising for undergraduate business students. Course includes 5 quarterly class meetings plus 1-4 hours per week of direct advising experience.

otherRequirements.requirementName: Leavey School of Business Peer Advisor
otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a Leavey School of Business Peer Advisor.

courses.name: The Global Fellow Experience
courses.description: The introductory course introduces students to the macro issues and challenges faced by the underserved populations of the world and provides a context for evaluating the global costs of injustice. Through the framework of business and organizational operations, students develop the tools to evaluate best practices as applied to living a civic life. Students will be exposed to academic research, guest speakers, interactive exercises, and readings in preparation for their summer fellowship, where the course learning will be applied to a work experience.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a Global Fellows participant.

courses.name: The Global Fellow Experience
courses.description: The reflection course segment is designed for students who spent time during the summer as Global Fellows. The primary goal of the course is to allow each student to reflect upon their experience and deepen their lessons learned. The secondary goal is to have the Global Fellows share their experience with the SCU community, thus bringing awareness of global issues to a wider audience.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a Global Fellows participant.

courses.otherNotes: In certain cases, the reflection segment fulfills the core requirement for ELSJ.

courses.name: Leadership Practicum
courses.description: Opportunity for business students to obtain advanced experience in leading, facilitating, directing, evaluating, and advising within a Leavey School of Business schoolwide or interdisciplinary project, class, or initiative. This practicum generally includes selected readings, reflective engagement activity, personal leadership assessment, and writing assignments.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Requires approval of the assistant dean.

courses.name: Internship/Practicum
courses.description: Opportunity for upper-division students—typically involved with schoolwide or interdisciplinary programs, projects, or initiatives—to work and study in or with for-profit and nonprofit organizations. This practicum generally includes selected readings, a reflective engagement activity, and a written report.

otherRequirements.requirementName: Approval of the senior assistant dean or associate dean
otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Requires approval of the senior assistant dean or associate dean.
May be included as fulfilling a requirement for a major only with permission of that department chair.

courses.name: Transformations of Energy and Matter L&L
courses.description: How do organisms obtain elements from their environment, change them to suit their growth needs, and acquire the energy necessary to sustain life? How do changing environments impact organisms and ecosystems? Students will explore the global cycle of critical elements and dissect the chemical reactions that incorporate these elements into biological molecules and new biological structures. They will discuss the implications of nutrient availability on growth of a variety of organisms and on interacting populations in an ecosystem. Core to this class is the exploration of the habits of mind that will form the basis of critical scientific thinking throughout the biology curriculum including collaborative learning, data interpretation, and communication. Laboratory 15 hours.

courses.name: Information and Evolution L&L
courses.description: This course builds an introductory understanding of how information is transmitted and utilized in biological systems. Students will investigate how the genetic transmission of information at the molecular, organismal, and population level generates biodiversity and drives evolution. In their studies, students will continue to practice the habits of mind necessary to critically evaluate data and communicate with the greater scientific community. Laboratory 15 hours.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Completion of BIOL1A with a C- or better

courses.name: Systems L&L
courses.description: All biological phenomena are complex networks whose components comprise molecules, cells, organs, organisms, and ecosystems. The stability of these networks is maintained by important feedback and feedforward regulations but alterations affecting one of the components could affect the entire network. In this course, students will model biological systems (e.g., cellular signaling pathways, organismal body plans, human diseases, endangered natural habitats) in order to predict how they will respond and adapt to changes in components and environmental conditions. Students will also apply the process of science to collect, analyze, and interpret data across biological scales and communicate with the greater scientific community. Laboratory 30 hours.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Completion of BIOL1B with a C- or better

courses.name: Human Health and Disease L&L
courses.description: This course will provide an overview of the biology of the human body. Students will explore the normal function of major organ systems at the physiological, cellular and molecular levels. We will discuss topics such as chronic and infectious diseases, immunity, nutrition, genetics, fitness, reproduction and inheritance. Laboratory 15 hours.
courses.otherNotes: Does not satisfy the requirements of the biology major.

courses.name: Fitness Physiology L&L
courses.description: Although many people rarely engage in vigorous exercise, as a species we evolved to perform prolonged, strenuous activity. This course surveys how exercise promotes a state of wellness and explores both the immediate responses to exercise as well as how the body responds to long-term training programs. In addition to learning basic human physiology, at the end of the course students should be able to critique and design experiments, understand and interpret reports of health and exercise news in the popular press, critically evaluate fitness claims made by advertisers, and recognize quackery. Laboratory 15 hours.
courses.otherNotes: Does not satisfy the requirements of the biology major.

courses.name: The Message of Ecology L&L
courses.description: An overview of earth’s ecosystems and the major factors contributing to the loss of biodiversity. Three major themes are explored: (1) general ecological principles, especially focused on the structure and function of ecosystems; (2) factors contributing to the endangerment of ecosystems; and (3) the conservation of ecosystems and biodiversity. This course discusses global environmental problems, and includes several lectures highlighting current environmental and conservation issues here in California and within the San Francisco Bay Area. Laboratory 15 hours.
courses.otherNotes: Does not satisfy the requirements of the biology major.

courses.name: Oceans L&L
courses.description: This course examines major ocean ecosystems and their inhabitants, with special attention paid to issues of governmental policy, sustainability, and human impacts on marine ecosystems. Laboratory and field activities will emphasize hands-on exploration of local marine habitats. Laboratory 15 hours.
courses.otherNotes: Does not satisfy the requirements of the biology major.

courses.name: Exploring Animal Behavior L&L
courses.description: A survey of modern scientific approaches that seek to understand why animals do what they do in nature, with a particular emphasis on evolutionary questions using case studies as models. Covers methods for posing and for testing hypotheses, data analysis and interpretation, and hands-on work with live animals in the laboratory and/or field settings. Laboratory: 15 hours.
courses.otherNotes: Does not satisfy the requirements of the biology major.

courses.name: Microbes and Humanity L&L
courses.description: The microbial world constantly surrounds and permeates humanity, and affects people in far more ways than “just” a global pandemic. This course introduces basic concepts of microbiology, explores harmful and helpful interactions between people and microbes in our everyday lives, and critically examines the impact of infectious diseases in medicine and public health. Laboratory experiments will use tools from clinical and food microbiology to illustrate and encourage scientific exploration. Laboratory: 15 hours.
courses.otherNotes: Does not satisfy the requirements of the biology major.

courses.name: Exploring Biotechnology L&L
courses.description: Have you ever wondered about the science behind CSI, “Frankenfoods,” human cloning, or how biofuels might help combat global warming? This course will examine the science underlying biotechnology: how DNA, genes, and cells work, and how they can be used in new technologies that affect many areas of our lives, including medical diagnosis and treatment, forensics, agriculture, and energy. We will discuss current developments in biotechnology and also examine the controversies and ethical considerations that accompany them. Laboratory experiments will focus on hypothesis testing and experimental design, and include detecting antibiotic-resistant bacteria, modeling the spread of diseases, performing human genetic testing, and testing common foods for genetic modification. Laboratory 15 hours.
courses.otherNotes: Does not satisfy the requirements of the biology major.

courses.name: Big Ideas in Biology
courses.description: Students in this course will explore foundational ideas that are at the root of many biological phenomena. In addition, students will discuss strategies for exploring their own curiosity, connect their learning in non-biology courses to their interests in biology, and discuss the vast arrays of career opportunities that individuals with a background in biology can pursue. Bring your curiosity, your lived experience, your questions and let’s explore together.
courses.otherNotes: Does not satisfy the requirements of the biology major.

courses.name: Biology Research Seminar
courses.description: A forum for the exploration of research in the life sciences. Invited scientists from a range of universities, institutes, and the private sector present their current research, and engage in discussion about this research with seminar participants. This course is intended to give students direct interactions with research academics in a range of fields to make them aware of career opportunities and to provide them with contacts in those fields.

courses.name: Human Anatomy L&L
courses.description: The human body is an incredible achievement of a multitude of different organs working together to promote life. These organs come in many different shapes, sizes, and structures, and are composed of different tissues, which reflect their specialized roles and functions. In this course, we will take a tour of the anatomical regions of the body, learning the names, locations, and features of the organs (bones, muscles, nervous system, blood vessels, etc.) and how they are arranged so that they may fulfill their functions. Lab activities will include microanatomy (histology), organ dissections, and the use of models to reinforce the anatomical relationships learned in lecture.

courses.name: Biology of Human Nutrition and Metabolism
courses.description: This course focuses both on how the body processes food and on how the resulting nutrients affect human physiology. The course will also explore such topics as the biological basis of eating disorders, ideal body weight, nutritional supplements, and the influence of nutrition on athletic performance.

courses.name: Health Consequences of a Western Lifestyle
courses.description: This course explores the impact of living in a developed country on human health. Topics such as diabetes, obesity, heart disease, hypertension, and cancer will be discussed at the molecular, cellular, physiological, and population levels.

courses.name: Genetics and Society
courses.description: Upper-division course designed for non-science majors interested in exploring the interplay between the social, scientific, and technological dimensions of human genetics. In addition to studying the nature of DNA (the genetic material), students will study the social and technological dimensions of current topics in genetics, including the Human Genome Project, paternity testing, crime scene investigation, embryo testing to select specific genotypes, personalized medicine, evolution, etc. Does not satisfy the requirements of the biology major.

courses.name: Genetics L&L
courses.description: Basic principles governing inheritance and gene expression in viruses, prokaryotes, and eukaryotes. Emphasis on molecular aspects. Laboratory 30 hours.

courses.name: Zoonoses and Emerging Infectious Diseases
courses.description: Zoonoses (diseases transmitted from animals to humans), emerging, and re-emerging infectious diseases increasingly threaten health security worldwide. This course focuses on their etiologies, epidemiology, prevention, diagnostic and treatment strategies; and how human behaviors and societal trends contribute to their rise.

courses.name: Immunology L&L
courses.description: Principles, mechanisms, and techniques of humoral and cellular aspects of the immune response. Immediate and delayed hypersensitivity, tissue transplantation, tumor immunology, and immunodeficient states in humans. Laboratory 30 hours.

courses.name: Microbiology L&L
courses.description: An introduction to the biology of microorganisms, with emphasis on the molecular and cellular biology of bacteria, the diversity of microbial life, and the roles of microorganisms in human health and disease. Laboratory 30 hours.

courses.name: Advanced Writing in Cell Biology L&L
courses.description: In this course, students integrate scientific information literacy, scientific writing, and cell biological concepts. The laboratory component of the course is designed to guide the development of narrative writing skills, critical editing, and revision skills to express complex ideas clearly and completely. Laboratory 30 hours.

courses.name: Human Reproduction and Development L&L
courses.description: Detailed study of the development and function of the male and female reproductive systems, gametogenesis, fertilization and implantation, and the anatomy of the heart, circulatory, nervous, and skeletal systems during embryogenesis. Where appropriate, the molecular mechanisms controlling the determination of these developing systems will be examined. Laboratory 30 hours.

courses.name: Medical Microbiology L&L
courses.description: This course focuses on the interactions of pathogenic microbes (bacteria, viruses, fungi, prions, etc.) with their hosts. The various strategies employed by the infectious agents to subvert the immune system and the various strategies used by the immune system to combat the microbial invasion will be examined, as will the co-evolution of hosts and their pathogens and the natural history of diseases. The laboratory component will expose students to clinical methodologies and scientific approaches to diagnose and differentiate pathogenic microorganisms.

courses.name: Epidemiology L&L
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to epidemiology, including assessment of health and disease in populations, epidemiological data analysis, disease transmission, and public health interventions. The course also exposes students to the epidemiology of diseases and conditions of current public health and clinical importance in the United States and internationally. The laboratory (computer lab) will provide students with hands-on experience with epidemiologic methods, study design, and data analysis.

courses.name: Biology of Stress
courses.description: This course explores the impact of stress on physiology, behavior, and health, using a multidisciplinary approach. Topics include defining and measuring stress, differences between acute and chronic stress exposure, effects of stress on physiological processes and on the brain, how stress affects gene expression and neurogenesis, and relationships between stress and disease. We will also discuss the social patterning of stress exposure and the effects of social policies and interventions.

courses.name: Animal Physiology L&L
courses.description: This course examines contrasting strategies used by different animals to deal with variations in temperature, food, oxygen, and water, and highlights the diversity of physiological adaptations in major animal groups, especially those living in extreme habitats. Laboratory 30 hours.

courses.name: Neurobiology L&L
courses.description: Study of the molecular basis of neurobiology: how the nervous system is structured, how neurons form connections and relay information between each other, and how specific components of the nervous system function together to perceive the environment around us. Laboratory 30 hours.

courses.name: Neurodevelopment L&L
courses.description: This course explores the development of the nervous system, including the cellular and molecular mechanisms that are crucial for the formation of the brain and spinal cord, and the establishment, maintenance, and remodeling of neuronal connections. We will also examine the experimental approaches used to study neural development. Laboratory 30 hours.

courses.name: Human Physiology L&L
courses.description: This course explores functional aspects of the human organism at the chemical, molecular, cellular, and tissue levels, with an emphasis on neural and endocrine control of physiological processes to maintain homeostasis. Laboratory 30 hours.

courses.name: Plant Development L&L
courses.description: This course explores the processes of RNA and protein regulation, epigenetics, and omics-based scientific approaches, phenomena that will be discussed within the context of plant development. Similarities and salient differences among and/or between plants, animals, and microbes will be described as appropriate. Laboratory 30 hours.

courses.name: California Plant Diversity L&L
courses.description: Surveys the major angiosperm families in California, relies heavily on using taxonomic keys to identify California plants to species, and investigates evolutionary patterns characteristic of the California flora through a combination of lab and substantial field experiences. Laboratory and field work 30 hours.

courses.name: Natural History of California L&L
courses.description: An examination of the natural history, biology and ecology of coastal, desert and marine ecosystems of California. This course counts as an Advanced Writing elective. Lecture explores biological and environmental issues critical to all the denizens of California. To explore issues of development, sustainability, and human ecology in California such as water, pollution, urban growth, and climate change students will conduct a term-long research project on a relevant topic of their choice, culminating in a paper and a short oral report to their peers. Lab 30 hours. Fieldwork will develop field observation and species identification skills and modern biodiversity indexing techniques in a variety of regional ecosystems, including rocky intertidal, tidal marsh, nearshore subtidal/kelp forest, redwood forest and oak woodlands.

courses.name: Natural History of Baja L&L
