courses.description: This course examines how Shakespeare's works form, channel, and contest ideologies of race, social class, religious chauvinism, and gender in both the early modern era and our present moment. Key topics include anti-blackness, geohumoralism, colonialism, caste, biological reproduction, monogenesis, blood lineage, pedigree, and embodied difference.

courses.name: LGBTQ Studies: U.S. Perspectives
courses.description: Interdisciplinary study of gay and lesbian cultures and critical theory with a focus on U.S. perspectives.
courses.otherNotes: May be repeated for credit when topics differ. Also listed as WGST136.

courses.name: LGBTQ Studies: Global Perspectives
courses.description: Interdisciplinary study of gay and lesbian cultures and critical theory with a focus on global perspectives.
courses.otherNotes: May be repeated for credit when topics differ. Also listed as WGST122.

courses.name: In Memory of Toni Morrison
courses.description: For course description, see ETHN131.

courses.name: American Environmental Literature
courses.description: Study of the natural world and its representations in American language and cultures.

courses.name: Global Environmental Literature
courses.description: Study of the natural world and its representations in global languages and cultures, in English or in translation.

courses.name: Postcolonial Literature and Theory
courses.description: Study of literature in the context of postcolonial theory and criticism.

courses.name: African Literature
courses.description: Thematic study of African literature in translation or written in English with attention to non-Western traditions of writing and to historical and social contexts and/or genre.

courses.name: South Asian Literature
courses.description: Thematic study of South Asian literature in translation or written in English with attention to historical and social contexts and/or genre.

courses.name: Caribbean Literature
courses.description: Thematic study of Caribbean literature in translation or written in English with attention to historical and social contexts and/or genre.

courses.name: Children’s Literature
courses.description: Study of the theory and practice of children’s literature with special attention to the history of children’s literature, the debate over the kinds of texts best suited for teaching reading, and multiculturalism.

courses.name: The Bible as Literature
courses.description: Literary genres of the Bible (myth, history, wisdom, prophecy, gospel) studied in translations from the Hebrew and Greek against the background of Mesopotamian, Babylonian, Egyptian, Hellenistic, and Roman cultures.

courses.name: Literature, Ethics, and Religion
courses.description: Exploration and analysis of central connections between religious and ethical questions, concerns, topics, and movements and their literary expressions in different social, cultural, individual, historical, geographical, and/or political contexts. When listed as 162GS, this course offers a gender studies focus.

courses.name: Literature and Performance
courses.description: For course description see THTR172.

courses.name: Topics in Theatre & Drama
courses.description: For course description see THTR112 or THTR113.
courses.otherNotes: Also listed as THTR112 or THTR113.

courses.name: Dramaturgy
courses.description: For course description see THTR185.

courses.name: Literature and Women
courses.description: Studies in literature by and about women.
courses.otherNotes: When listed as 168AM, also listed as WGST167 and offers a gender studies focus; when listed as 168GL, offers a global focus. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.

courses.name: Women, Literature, and Theory
courses.description: Study of literature by and about women in explicitly theoretical contexts.
courses.otherNotes: When listed as 169AM, also listed as WGST166 and offers an American literature focus; when listed as 169GL, offers a global literature focus. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.

courses.name: Writing for Children and Young Adults
courses.description: Workshop in writing and illustrating children’s and young adults’ books.

courses.name: Advanced Fiction Writing
courses.description: Writing fiction, with emphasis on the short story.

courses.name: Advanced Poetry Writing
courses.description: Workshop in the writing of poetry.

courses.name: Screenwriting
courses.description: Introduction to the fundamentals and format of screenplay writing. Critical analysis of characterization and narrative structure in contemporary movies, as well as workshops in the writing of film treatments, outlines, and scripts.
courses.otherNotes: May be repeated for credit. Also listed as THTR173.

courses.name: Advanced Creative Nonfiction
courses.description: Development of skills in the elements of creative nonfiction, such as narration, character development, persona, and voice. Focus is on one or more modes of creative nonfiction, such as landscape writing, popular culture, literary journalism, profile, and memoir.

courses.name: Creative Writing and Social Justice
courses.description: Explores the intersections of creative writing, social justice, and vocation with special attention to issues of poverty and homelessness. Students will read and write creative prose and poetry, have a brief community placement, and learn from several guest speakers.

courses.name: Writing Genre Fiction
courses.description: Introduction to and practice in planning and drafting works of genre fiction (such as historical, science fiction, magical realism, fantasy) for an adult or young adult audience.

courses.name: Creative Writing and Performing
courses.description: Students will experiment with writing and performing in a range of styles, such as spoken word, storytelling, flash fiction and collaborative performances, poetry and music, and monologues. The course will culminate in a student performance.

courses.name: Advanced Playwriting
courses.description: For course description see THTR171.

courses.name: Playwriting
courses.description: For description see THTR170.
courses.otherNotes: Also listed as THTR170. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.

courses.name: Engineering Communications: Practical Writing and Presentation Skills for Engineers
courses.description: Focus is on effective written and oral communication specifically targeted for engineers in the industrial environment. Major topics include audience analysis, document design, revision, the design and use of graphics, ethical issues in communications, multimodal communication methods, and oral presentation techniques.
courses.otherNotes: Open primarily to junior and senior engineering majors.

courses.name: Professional/Digital Writing Internship
courses.description: Applied introduction to designing, iterating, managing, and testing digital projects across modes and platforms for professional purposes (including industry, non-profit, and public sector). Internship is on-site, guided by professional writing faculty. Students will conduct user-experience research and generate content for SCU affiliated websites and social media accounts, generating a portfolio of work to document their learning, and showcase their skills.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Enrollment by permission: use this form to apply (http://bit.do/ENGL_189).

courses.name: Senior Seminar
courses.description: Special topics in English, American, or comparative literature for senior English majors.

courses.name: Peer Educator in English
courses.description: Peer educators are invited by faculty to work closely with them, facilitating learning in a lower-division course.
courses.otherNotes: May be repeated for credit by permission of the instructor.

courses.name: Special Topics II
courses.description: Specific authors, genres, literary or theoretical movements, or themes.
courses.otherNotes: May be repeated for credit when topics differ.

courses.name: Writing Internship
courses.description: Work-study program for students of superior writing ability who gain course credit by supervised writing for newspapers, magazines, or for government or private agencies. Students are graded P/NP only.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: By permission or invitation of the director of internships and department chair.

courses.otherNotes: May be repeated once for credit.

courses.name: Writing Studio Internship
courses.description: For students of superior writing ability, intensive practice preparing work for publication under the supervision of distinguished writing faculty. Students should have significant work in progress. Students are graded P/NP only.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: By permission or invitation of the instructor and the department chair.

courses.otherNotes: May be repeated once for credit.

courses.name: Directed Reading/Directed Research
courses.description: In special circumstances and with permission of the department chair, a student may request a course in directed reading or writing from an instructor. May not be taken in a subject listed in this Bulletin.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Permission of the department chair required.

courses.name: Engineering Graphics and Computer-Aided Design I
courses.description: An introduction to engineering graphics and computer-aided design (CAD) using a 3D solid modeling software package. Topics include geometric construction, sketching, orthographic projection, isometric, and sectional views. Drawing and CAD laboratory classes will consist of lectures and exercises, demonstrations, and student work sessions.

courses.name: Materials and Manufacturing Processes
courses.description: The principles of manufacturing processes as related to materials properties, design, and production. A review of structures, properties, and manufacturing processes for main groups of engineering materials including metals and metallic alloys, polymers, and ceramics.

courses.name: Engineering Graphics and Computer Aided Design II
courses.description: Continuation of MECH 10L. An introduction to engineering graphics and computer-aided design (CAD) using a 3D solid modeling software package. Topics include dimensioning and tolerancing, descriptive geometry and auxiliary views, and assemblies. Drawing and CAD laboratory classes will consist of lectures and exercises, demonstrations, and student work sessions. Light machining will be introduced, as well.

courses.name: Engineering Graphics and CAD III
courses.description: An introduction to advanced computer-aided design (CAD) using an advanced 3D parametric surface and solid modeling commercial tool. Topics include Advanced surface modeling, sheet metal design, meldment structures, topology optimization tools, FEA tools, etc.

courses.name: Introduction to Materials Science
courses.description: Physical basis of the electrical, mechanical, optical, and thermal behavior of solids. Relations between micro/atomic structures, processing, and properties.

courses.name: Introduction to Materials Science Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory for MECH 15.

courses.name: Tools for Collegiate-centric Student Competitions
courses.description: Design and development of new student-centric projects that may follow a “concept design-to-build-and-test” type routine. Weekly student-faculty meetings, design reviews, research and prototype development presentations, industry tours, presentations from keynote speakers, etc.

courses.name: Applied Programming for Mechanical Engineers
courses.description: Computer programming in MATLAB, including: use of the development environment, m-files, and debugging; data structures; flow control, including loops, vectorization, and conditional statements; functions and variable scope; file input and output; plotting and visualization; selected topics in object-oriented programming. Applications to engineering problems including linear algebra and differential equations.

courses.name: Applied Programming for Mechanical Engineers Lab
courses.description: Laboratory for MECH 45.

courses.name: Machining Laboratory
courses.description: Practical experience with machine tools such as mills, lathes, band saws, etc. Basic training in safe and proper use of the equipment associated with simple mechanical projects. Laboratory. P/NP grading.

courses.name: Mathematical Methods in Mechanical Engineering
courses.description: Review of ordinary differential equations and Laplace transform; Fourier series; partial differential equations with applications to problems in vibration and heat conduction; and selected topics from linear algebra.

courses.name: Mathematical Methods in Mechanical Engineering Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for MECH 103.

courses.name: Machine Design I
courses.description: Analysis and design of mechanical systems for safe operation. Stress and deflection analysis. Failure theories for static loading and fatigue failure criteria. Team design projects begun. Formal conceptual design reports required.

courses.name: Machine Design II
courses.description: Continuation of MECH 114. Treatment of basic machine elements (e.g., bolts, springs, gears, bearings). Design and analysis of machine elements for static and fatigue loading. Team design projects completed. Design prototypes and formal final report required.

courses.name: Thermodynamics I
courses.description: Definitions of work, heat, and energy. First and second laws of thermodynamics. Properties of pure substances. Application to fixed-mass systems and control volumes. Irreversibility and device/cycle efficiencies.

courses.name: Thermodynamics I Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for MECH 121.

courses.name: Fluid Mechanics
courses.description: Fluid properties and definitions. Fluid statics, forces on submerged surfaces, manometry. Streamlines and conservation flow fields. Euler’s and Bernoulli’s equations. Mass, momentum, and energy analysis. Laminar and turbulent flows. Losses in pipes and ducts. Dimensional analysis and similitude. External flows.

courses.name: Fluid Mechanics Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory for MECH 122.

courses.name: Heat Transfer
courses.description: Introduction to the concepts of conduction, convection, and radiation heat transfer. Application of these concepts to engineering problems.

courses.name: Heat Transfer Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory work to understand the concept of heat transfer. Practical experience with temperature and heat flux measurement.

courses.name: Thermal Systems Design
courses.description: Analysis, design, and simulation of fluids and thermal engineering systems. Application of optimization techniques, life cycle, and sustainability concepts in these systems.

courses.name: Thermodynamics II
courses.description: Thermodynamic potential and availability, advanced power and refrigeration cycles, chemical equilibrium, advanced power and refrigeration cycles with non-reacting or reacting air/vapor mixture.

courses.name: Aerodynamics
courses.description: Fundamentals of aerodynamics. Governing equations (mass, momentum, energy). Inviscid, incompressible flow applied to subsonic air flow: Laplace’s equations and flow superposition, Kutta-Joukowski theorem and generation of lift. Incompressible flow over airfoils: Kutta condition, Kelvin circulation theorem. Lifting flow over arbitrary bodies. Incompressible flow over finite wings: downwash and induced drag. Introduction to fundamental principles of viscous flow and discussion of drag components.

courses.name: Dynamics
courses.description: Kinematics of particles in rectilinear and curvilinear motion. Kinetics of particles, Newton’s second law, energy and momentum methods. Systems of particles. Kinematics and kinetics of plane motion of rigid bodies, energy and momentum methods. Introduction to three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies.

courses.name: Dynamics Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for MECH 140.

courses.name: Mechanical Vibrations
courses.description: Fundamentals of vibration, free and forced vibration of undamped/damped single degree and two-degree of freedom systems. Vibration under general forcing conditions. Determination of natural frequencies and mode shapes.

courses.name: Mechanical Vibrations Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory for MECH 141.

courses.name: Feedback Control Systems
courses.description: Introduction to system theory, transfer functions, and state space modeling of physical systems. Course topics include stability, analysis and design of PID, Lead/Lag, other forms of controllers in time and frequency domains, root locus, Bode diagrams, state space pole placement, and gain and phase margins.

courses.name: Feedback Control Systems Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory for MECH 142.

courses.name: Mechatronics
courses.description: Introduction to behavior, design, and integration of electromechanical components and systems. Review of appropriate electronic components/circuitry, mechanism configurations, and programming constructs. Use and integration of transducers, microcontrollers, and actuators.

courses.name: Mechatronics Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory for MECH 143.

courses.name: Smart Product Design
courses.description: Design of innovative smart electromechanical devices and products. Topics include a review of the basics of mechanical, electrical, and software design and prototyping, and will emphasize the synthesis of functional systems that solve a customer need, that are developed in a team-based environment, and which are informed by the use of methodologies from the fields of systems engineering, concurrent design, and project/business management. Designs will be developed in the context of a cost-constrained business environment, and principles of accounting, marketing, and supply chain are addressed. Societal impacts of technical products and services are reviewed. Enrollment is controlled in order to have a class with students from diverse majors.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Core Foundation-level natural science and mathematics or equivalent

courses.name: Smart Product Design Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory for MECH 144.

courses.name: Introduction to Aerospace Engineering
courses.description: Basic design and analysis of atmospheric flight vehicles. Principles of aerodynamics, propulsion, structures and materials, flight dynamics, stability and control, mission analysis, and performance estimation. Introduction to orbital dynamics.

courses.name: Mechanism Design
courses.description: Kinematic analysis and synthesis of planar mechanisms. Graphical synthesis of linkages and cams. Graphical and analytical techniques for the displacement, velocity, and acceleration analysis of mechanisms. Computer-aided design of mechanisms. Three or four individual mechanism design projects.

courses.name: Finite Element Theory and Applications
courses.description: Basic introduction to finite elements; direct and variational basis for the governing equations; elements and interpolating functions. Applications to general field problems: elasticity, fluid mechanics, and heat transfer. Extensive use of software packages.

courses.name: Composite Materials
courses.description: Analysis of composite materials and structures. Calculation of properties and failure of composite laminates. Manufacturing considerations and design of simple composite structures. Knowledge of MATLAB or equivalent programming environment is required.

courses.name: Aerospace Structures
courses.description: This introductory course presents the application of fundamental theories of elasticity and stress analysis to aerospace structures. Course topics include fundamentals of elasticity, virtual work and matrix methods, bending and buckling of thin plates, component load analysis, and airframe loads, torsion shear, and bending of thin-walled sections.

courses.name: Astrodynamics
courses.description: This course provides the foundations of basic gravitation and orbital theory. Topics include Review of particle dynamics, classical orbital elements, basic transformation matrices, ground tracks, Hohmann transfer, coplanar rendezvous, combined change maneuver, and interplanetary flight.

courses.name: Introduction to Nanotechnology
courses.description: Introduction to the field of nanoscience and nanotechnology. Properties of nanomaterials and devices. Nanoelectronics: from silicon and beyond. Measurements of nanosystems. Applications and implications. Laboratory experience is an integral part of the course.

courses.name: Introduction to Nanotechnology Laboratory
courses.description: Optional laboratory for MECH 156.

courses.name: Engineering Simulations and Modeling
courses.description: Simulation and modeling of solids and fluids using modern computational methods. Application of finite element modeling techniques to analyze mechanical systems subjected to various types of loading. Heat conduction and fluid interaction effects with solids. Transient problems including vibrations. Practical experience gained in using commercial simulation packages and interacting with CAD systems. Review of basic finite element theory with particular attention to modeling loads, constraints and materials.

courses.name: Aerospace Propulsion Systems
courses.description: Fundamentals of air breathing and rocket jet propulsion. Gas dynamics fundamentals, review of thermodynamic relation. Basic theory of aircraft gas turbine engines, propulsive efficiency, and application of Brayton cycle to gas turbine engine analysis. Rocket engine nozzle configuration and design. Thrust Equation. Chemical rocket engine fundamentals. Solid versus liquid propellant rockets.

courses.name: Engineering and Design with Applied Machine Learning
courses.description: Learn how to apply techniques from Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning to solve engineering problems and design new products or systems. Design and build a personal or research project that demonstrates how computational learning algorithms can solve difficult tasks in areas students are interested in. Master how to interpret and transfer state-of-the-art techniques from computer science to practical engineering situations and make smart implementation decisions.

courses.name: Modern Instrumentation for Engineers
courses.description: Introduction to engineering instrumentation, sensors, electric circuits, computer data acquisition, hardware and software, sampling theory, statistics, and error analysis. Theory of pressure, temperature, acceleration, and strain measurement.

courses.name: Modern Instrumentation for Engineers Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory work spans the disciplines of mechanical engineering: dynamics, controls, fluids, heat transfer, and thermodynamics, with emphasis on report writing. Students will design their own experiment and learn how to set up instrumentation using computer data acquisition hardware and software.

courses.name: Materials Selection and Design
courses.description: Design considerations in the use of materials; materials selection for optimizing multiple properties; materials failure modes and failure mechanism; materials selection to prevent failure; case studies and discussions on process economics, life-cycle thinking, and eco-design. Ansys Granta EduPack will be introduced as a materials and processes database and a tool for students to compare, analyze, and select materials and processes.

courses.name: Special Topics in Material, Mechanics, Manufacturing, and Design
courses.description: Technical Elective in the area of material, mechanics, manufacturing, and design. A new topic in the area will be introduced. Topics vary every time it is offered.

courses.name: Special Topics in Thermofluids and Energy
courses.description: Technical Elective in the area of thermofluids and energy. A new topic in the area will be introduced. Topics vary every time it is offered.

courses.name: Special Topics in Dynamics, Controls, and Robotics
courses.description: Technical Elective in the area of dynamics, controls, and robotics. A new topic in the area will be introduced. Topics vary every time it is offered.

courses.name: Continuum Mechanics
courses.description: General introduction to the mechanics of continuous media. Topics include the kinematics of deformation, the concept of stress, and the balance laws for mass, momentum, and energy. This is followed by an introduction to constitutive theory with applications to established models for viscous fluids and elastic solids. Concepts are illustrated through the solution of tractable initial-boundary-value problems.

courses.name: Satellite Operations Laboratory
courses.description: This laboratory course reviews the physical principles and control techniques appropriate to communicating with, commanding, and monitoring spacecraft. Students learn to operate real satellite tracking, commanding, and telemetry systems, and to perform spacecraft-specific operations using approved procedures. Given the operational status of the system, students may conduct these operations on orbiting NASA spacecraft and interact with NASA scientists and engineers as part of operations processes.

courses.name: Co-op Education
courses.description: Practical experience in a planned program designed to give students practical work experience related to their academic field of study and career objectives. Satisfactory completion of the assignment includes preparation of a summary report on co-op activities.
courses.otherNotes: P/NP grading. May be taken for graduate credit.

courses.name: Co-op Technical Report
courses.description: Credit given for a technical report on a specific activity such as a design or research project after completing the co-op assignment. Letter grades are based on content and presentation quality of report.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Approval of the department co-op advisor is required

courses.name: Mechanical Engineering Project Manufacturing
courses.description: Laboratory course that provides supervised evening access to the machine shop and/or light fabrication area for qualified mechanical engineering students to work on their University-directed projects. Students wishing to utilize the machine shop or light fabrication during the evening lab/shop hours are required to enroll. Enrollment in any section allows students to attend any/all evening shop hours on a drop-in basis. Staff or faculty will be present during each scheduled meeting to supervise as well as be available for consultation and manufacturing advising.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Passing grade on the Mechanical Engineering Lab Safety Test
Successful completion of the Light Fabrication Training Seminar

courses.name: Peer Educator in Mechanical Engineering
courses.description: Peer Educators in Mechanical Engineering work closely with a faculty member to help students understand course material; think more deeply about course material; benefit from collaborative learning; feel less anxious about testing situations; and/or to help students enjoy learning.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Enrollment is by permission of the instructor

courses.name: Advanced Design I: Tools
courses.description: Design tools basic to all aspects of mechanical engineering, including design methodology, computer-design tools, simulation, engineering economics, and decision making. Senior design projects begin.

courses.name: Advanced Design II: Implementation
courses.description: Implementation of design strategy. Detail design and fabrication of senior design projects. Quality control, testing and evaluation, standards and specifications, and human factors.

courses.name: Advanced Design III: Completion and Evaluation
courses.description: Design projects completed, assembled, tested, evaluated, and judged with opportunities for detailed re-evaluation by the designers. Formal public presentation of results. Final written report required.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: By arrangement with faculty.

courses.name: Directed Research/Reading
courses.description: Investigation of an engineering problem and writing an acceptable report.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Weekly meetings with a faculty advisor are required

courses.otherNotes: Up to 8 units can be considered as technical electives.

courses.name: Elementary Latin I
courses.description: Introduction to vocabulary, forms, and grammar of classical Latin. Development of reading skills with supporting exercises in writing.

courses.name: Elementary Latin II
courses.description: Continuation of Latin I.

courses.name: Elementary Latin III
courses.description: Completion of elementary Latin.

courses.name: Intermediate Latin
courses.description: A course for students who have finished basic Latin grammar. Students will review Latin forms and syntax while reading prose and poetry of increasing complexity. Students will be prepared to enroll in Latin reading courses covering individual authors and genres. Offered in fall quarter only.

courses.name: Caesar
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Representative selections from the Commentarii on the Gallic War and/or Bellum Civile. Consideration of the adaptation of history to political ends.

courses.name: Catullus
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Lyric poems, short epigrams, and longer mythological poems by the poet Catullus, of the late Roman Republic.

courses.name: Roman Comedy
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. One or more plays by Plautus or Terence. Social function and nature of Roman comedy.

courses.name: Ovid: Metamorphoses
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Selections from Ovid’s epic compendium of mythology.

courses.name: Cicero: Philosophical Works
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Consideration of Cicero’s eclectic philosophy through a careful reading of one or more of his philosophical dialogues.

courses.name: Cicero: Oratory and Rhetoric
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. One or more exemplars of Cicero’s rhetorical style or rhetorical theory. Consideration of rhetorical forms, figures, and topoi.

courses.name: Vergil: Aeneid
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. The epic poem on the effort of founding Rome and the cost of its greatness. Consideration of the traditional and innovative features of Vergil’s epic style and purpose. Attention to epic meter.

courses.name: Seneca: Tragedies
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Careful reading and discussion of a play by Seneca, with particular consideration of Seneca’s cultural context and importance in literary history, including his influence on later dramatists such as Shakespeare.

courses.name: Roman Novel
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Students will study a Roman Novel, with selections read in Latin and supplementary materials in English. Possible texts include Petronius’s Satyricon, a trenchant satire of Roman society composed under Nero; and Apuleius’s Golden Ass, the grim yet ribald tale of a man who accidentally turns himself into a donkey.

courses.name: Roman Elegy
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Representative selections from the works of Tibullus, Propertius, and Ovid. Origins and development of the elegiac genre.

courses.name: Vergil: Eclogues and Georgics
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Vergil’s earlier works: pastoral poems set in an idealized landscape and the didactic poem on the agriculture and countryside of his native Italy.

courses.name: Horace
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Selections from the odes and epodes. Attention to cultural context and the adaptation of Greek lyric forms and rhythms to the Latin language.

courses.name: Livy
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Selections from the Ab Urbe Condita—the history of Rome from its semi-mythical founding through monarchy, early Republic, and Punic Wars.

courses.name: Roman Letters
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Selections from letters by various authors: Cicero, Seneca, Pliny. Discussion of the epistle as a literary genre, with focus on the social and historical background of the author.

courses.name: Late Antique and Medieval Latin
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Major works of prose and poetry from the fourth century to the Renaissance. St. Augustine’s Confessions; Boethius’s Consolation of Philosophy; the histories of Gregory of Tours, Bede, and Einhard; Latin fables; popular songs such as the Carmina Burana; and the humanistic writings of Dante, Boccaccio, and Petrarch.

courses.name: Roman Historians
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Selections from Roman historians such as Tacitus or Sallust. Focus on the construction of history as both a literary genre and academic discipline, as well as how Romans constructed their own history.

courses.name: Latin Biography
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Selections from Suetonius and/or Cornelius Nepos. Focus on the genre of biography and the cultural contexts of the authors and subjects.

courses.name: Martial
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Selections from Martial’s epigrams. Focus on the genre of epigram, Martial’s poetic style, and the relationship between Martial’s poetry and his cultural context.

courses.name: Special Topics in Latin Poetry
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Occasional courses in selected authors or genres for advanced students. Possible topics: Lucretius, Lucan, or satire.

courses.name: Special Topics in Latin Prose
courses.description: Reading course in Latin. Occasional courses in selected authors or genres for advanced students. Possible topics: Quintillian, Varro, Aulus Gellius.

courses.name: Myth through Introductory Greek I
courses.description: Learn to read Ancient Greek by reading Ancient Greek works about mythology in their original language.

courses.name: Myth through Introductory Greek II
courses.description: Continuation of CLAS 21.

courses.name: Myth through Introductory Greek III
courses.description: Completion of Myth through Introductory Greek sequence.

courses.name: Lucian
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. Selections from the author’s satirical treatments of mythology, history, philosophy, and rhetoric and/or from the fantasy called A True Story. Lucian’s place in the Second Sophistic.

courses.name: Homer: Odyssey
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. Selected passages demonstrating the exploration of the heroic ethos in an epic of peacetime. Consideration of epic meter and conventions.

courses.name: Euripides
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. A complete tragic drama. Attention to characterization, dramatic structure, poetry, and Euripides’ place in the history of tragedy.

courses.name: Herodotus
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. Selections from the Persian Wars. Focus on Herodotus’ prose style, narrative form, world view, and achievements as the “Father of History.” Peculiarities of the Ionic dialect.

courses.name: Plato
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. Careful reading from one or more dialogues such as Apology, Crito, Phaedo, and Republic. Detailed study of dialogue mode of discourse; overview of Plato’s philosophy.

courses.name: Greek New Testament
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. Readings selected from the Koine Greek text of the New Testament with a concentration on the gospels or the epistles. Close reading of the text with a view to theological implications of the vocabulary. Introduction to primary research tools.

courses.name: Hesiod
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. Selected readings from Hesiod’s two poems, Works and Days and Theogony.

courses.name: Xenophon
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. Selected readings from Xenophon’s Memorabilia, Anabasis, Cyropaedia or one of his other works. Focus on Xenophon’s style and cultural and historical context.

courses.name: Greek Novel
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. Selected chapters from one or more of the ancient Greek novels, paying particular attention to language and style. In addition to our reading, we will also explore the genre of the novel and the literary, historical, and social contexts surrounding the development of this literary phenomenon.

courses.name: Plutarch
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. Selected readings from Plutarch’s biographies or Moralia.

courses.name: Homer: Iliad
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. Selected passages illustrating the course and consequences of the wrath of Achilles and the nature of the hero. Consideration of epic meter and conventions.

courses.name: Sophocles
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. A complete tragic drama. Attention to characterization, dramatic structure, and poetry, and to the author’s particular contributions to the development of the tragic form. Metrical reading of the text.

courses.name: Aeschylus
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. A complete tragic drama. Attention to characterization, dramatic structure, and poetry, and to the author’s particular contributions to the development of the tragic form. Metrical reading of the text.

courses.name: Greek Oratory
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. Selections from a representative Greek orator such as Demosthenes or Lysias. Consideration of classical rhetorical forms, topoi, and cultural and historical context.

courses.name: Aristophanes
courses.description: Reading course in Greek. A complete comic drama. Attention to dramatic structure, characterization, poetry, political and social commentary, comedic style, and to Aristophanes’ place in the history of comedy.

courses.name: Special Topics in Greek Poetry
courses.description: Occasional courses in selected authors or genres for advanced students. Possible topics: Lyric, Homeric Hymns, or Pindar.

courses.name: Special Topics in Greek Prose
courses.description: Occasional courses in selected authors or genres for advanced students. Possible topics: Thucydides, Aristotle, or Marcus Aurelius.

courses.name: Ancient Mediterranean Religious Traditions
courses.description: An introduction to the beliefs and practices of religious traditions in the ancient Mediterranean world. Students will examine polytheistic, henotheistic, and monotheistic religions and their interactions with each other, particularly in cosmopolitan societies. Attention will be paid to ancient Egypt, Israel, Greece, Carthage, Rome, and the Celtic world.

courses.name: Cultures & Ideas I
courses.description: A two-course sequence focusing on a major theme in human experience and culture over a significant period of time. Courses emphasize either broad global interconnections, or the construction of Western culture in its global context. Courses will address significant texts, ideas, issues, and events in their historical context from a humanistic perspective. Classics topics include Friendship: Ancient and Modern, Gods and Mortals, Heroes and Heroism, Sports and Spectacle, Creating Barbarians, and Ancient Spaces.

courses.name: Cultures & Ideas II
courses.description: A two-course sequence focusing on a major theme in human experience and culture over a significant period of time. Courses emphasize either broad global interconnections, or the construction of Western culture in its global context. Courses will address significant texts, ideas, issues, and events in their historical context from a humanistic perspective. Classics topics include Friendship: Ancient and Modern, Gods and Mortals, Heroes and Heroism, Sports and Spectacle, Creating Barbarians, and Ancient Spaces.

courses.name: Greek Civilization
courses.description: An introductory overview that synthesizes central aspects of ancient Greek civilization to provide a general understanding of ancient Greek culture and its contributions to later societies. Topics include mythology, religion, history, theater, politics, art, philosophy, and gender. This course can be taken either as a lower-division course or as an upper-division course (CLAS 119).

courses.name: The Legacy of Rome
courses.description: What have the Romans ever done for us? This course provides an overview of ancient Roman culture and the fundamental role the Romans played in shaping western civilization. We will pay particular attention to the legacy of Roman civilization that continues to influence contemporary culture, whether for good or ill. Topics include the republicanism, concepts of time, literature, architecture, religion, and the purpose of education itself. And the aqueducts. And the wine.
courses.otherNotes: The course has no prerequisites. This course can be taken as CLAS 120 at the upper-division level.

courses.name: Word Workshop: Scientific Etymology
courses.description: This class will help you build your vocabulary and acquire the tools to figure out words that you do not already know by teaching you the basics of English word formation and some common Greek and Latin morphemes.

courses.name: Greek and Roman Heroes in Hollywood
courses.description: Movies have fascinated their audiences with Greek myths for decades but are notorious for playing fast and loose with the ancient stories. This course examines some cinematic versions of classical figures such as Perseus or Heracles and the classical sources they adapt for modern audiences. (topic varies).

courses.name: History of Philosophy: Classical and Medieval
courses.description: Beginnings of Western philosophy. Representative philosophers of the Greek and Medieval traditions, with attention to their historical milieu and their relevance to contemporary thought.

courses.name: Introduction to the Arts of Ancient and Medieval Europe
courses.description: Visual analysis of the ancient and medieval world. Topics may include the relationship between Greek art and politics, Imperial Roman art, propaganda, Pompeian wall painting, early Christian art, the origins of Islam, and the function and culture of pilgrimage in the Middle Ages.

courses.name: Ancient Monuments
courses.description: An exploration of the nature of political and religious authority: that is, the relationship between the individual, the state, and the divine—in three different ancient civilizations. The primary “texts” for this investigation are the representative monuments of each culture: the pyramids of Egypt (particularly the Old Kingdom), the Temple of Solomon in Jerusalem in the united monarchy, and the Parthenon.

courses.name: Ancient Empires
courses.description: The course examines the construction and manipulation of identities in three ancient empires—Achaemenid Persian, Seleucid, and Roman—as well as cultures on their peripheries. Both literary and material sources are used to study how the inhabitants and rulers of these large, cosmopolitan empires defined themselves.

courses.name: Sex and Religion in Ancient Greece: Ancient Eros
courses.description: This course explores the various manifestations and significance of sex (“Bittersweet Eros”), both the deity and the divinely-inspired passion, in ancient Greece. While this course focuses on examining the socio-religious significance of Aphrodite and her son, Eros (the Roman Cupid), it is also designed to provoke an open conversation about responses to sex found in relevant contemporary religious expression. Assignments are derived from Greek and Roman literature, philosophy, historiography, and art, as well as from contemporary magazines, scholarly journals and books, religious documents, and movies.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Participation in class discussion is mandatory for this seminar-style course.

courses.name: Classical Mythology
courses.description: Principal gods and heroes of Greek and Roman antiquity: their stories, significance, and pictorial representations. Implications of myth in society and possible origins of myth. Important background for European and English literature.

courses.name: Ancient Greek Religion
courses.description: Consideration of the differing attitudes and expectations of polytheisms and monotheisms, and of religious expression in the context of classical Greek cult and ritual. Readings are drawn from a wide variety of literary, historical, philosophical, and epigraphical texts.

courses.name: Ancient Roman Religion
courses.description: Examination of religious practices, institutions, and beliefs of the ancient Romans. Special consideration of interconnections in Roman religiosity between the acts/beliefs of individuals and the concerns of the state. Concludes with philosophic mysticism, magic, mystery religions, and Christianity.

courses.name: Classics in Cinema
courses.description: A survey of the classical world through selected dramatic films illustrating sequentially the cultural and political history of ancient Greece and Rome. Close viewings of popular films, with comparative reference to sources and practice in the techniques of film criticism.

courses.name: Hercules!
courses.description: While many people today may first encounter Hercules through the popular Disney movie, TV shows, or comic books, the original character of Hercules in the ancient world is much more complex than many of these current depictions convey. Not only powerful and brave, but also an adulterer and murderer, Hercules (or Heracles, as he is known to the ancient Greeks) struggles both literally and metaphorically on his path to immortality. Our class will examine various ancient and modern depictions of Hercules in order to understand the full picture of a truly complicated figure. This course can be taken either as a lower-division course or as an upper-division course (CLAS 183).

courses.name: Cultural Heritage and Collecting Antiquities
courses.description: This course will study the history of museums, art collecting, and art theft in the ancient world. It will explore the concept of cultural heritage to discuss what is shown in collections, and to critique what museums are choosing to show to the viewing public, and what this means for civic life. This class is an exploration of art collecting in the ancient world, the heritage of ancient art, and its presentation and preservation for the edification of the viewing public in our modern world. This course can be taken either as an upper-division course (CLAS 186) or lower-division course.

courses.name: Roman Art and Architecture
courses.description: This course surveys the development of art and architecture in the Roman world from the Iron Age through Late Antiquity. The course emphasizes the role of the state as well as political, social, and religious organizations in shaping Roman art, architecture, and material culture.

courses.name: Archaic Greek History: Scientists and Spartans
courses.description: Over three thousand years ago, this course examines how the ancient Greeks used inquiry and experimentation to deal with problems such as climate change, epidemic disease, and economic decline, and how these innovations forced social confrontations with issues like income inequality and environmental destruction, with parallels to contemporary technology–society relationships.

courses.name: Classical Greek History: Tyrants, Traitors, and Rebels
courses.description: A survey of Hellenic history from the Bronze Age to Alexander the Great, with emphasis on the rise and fall of the polis as an independent social, cultural, and political community.

courses.name: The Hellenistic Age
courses.description: A cultural, social, and political review of Alexander the Great’s conquests and their Hellenistic ramifications through the reign of Egypt’s Cleopatra VII.

courses.name: Roman Republic
courses.description: A political, military, social, and cultural review of the rise and fall of the most successful state the West has ever known.

courses.name: Roman Empire
courses.description: A political, social, and cultural survey of the Roman Empire beginning with Augustus and tracing changes in Rome from the development of the Roman Empire as a world state to the development of Christianity as a world religion.

courses.name: Democracy Under Siege: Ancient Athens and Modern America
courses.description: This course traces the fate of Athenian democracy from the archaic period through the Hellenistic Age (circa 594 to 307 BCE), covering both external and internal opposition, and draws parallels with 21st-century U.S. politics through readings and discussions.

courses.name: The Democratic City
courses.description: Students study the nature and history of ancient democracy by actively engaging as citizens in a model Greek democracy, collaborating, persuading, and debating to solve case studies based on real problems faced by ancient polities.

courses.name: Greek Art
courses.description: The course examines Greek art, architecture, and material culture from the Bronze Age through the Roman period, with special attention to development within political, historical, and cultural contexts.

courses.name: Art and Architecture of the Roman Republic and the Early Empire
courses.description: Chronological survey of artistic development in Republican and Imperial Rome, including Greek and Etruscan influences, political ideology in public art, and the impact of materials on building design.
courses.otherNotes: Cross-listed with AAH 106. This course satisfies the advanced writing requirement.

courses.name: Greek Civilization
courses.description: An introductory overview synthesizing central aspects of ancient Greek civilization—mythology, religion, history, theater, politics, art, philosophy, and gender—with the option to take as upper- or lower-division (CLAS 19).
courses.otherNotes: Can be taken as an upper-division or lower-division course (CLAS 19).

courses.name: The Legacy of Rome
courses.description: An overview of ancient Roman culture and its continuing influence on Western civilization, covering republicanism, concepts of time, literature, architecture, religion, education, aqueducts, and wine.
courses.otherNotes: No prerequisites. Can be taken as an upper-division or lower-division course (CLAS 20).

courses.name: Love and Relationships in Classical Antiquity
courses.description: An examination of loving and erotic relationships in Greek and Roman texts, with readings from Euripides, Sappho, Ovid, Plato, Aristotle, and others across poetry, essays, letters, tragedy, and philosophy.
courses.otherNotes: Also listed as PHIL 141D and WGST 133.

courses.name: Heretics and Holy Wars
courses.description: Exploration of religion and Mediterranean society between 235 and 622 CE, focusing on monasticism, pilgrimage, heresy, philosophy, and church-state and individual-divine relationships.

courses.name: Age of Socrates
courses.description: A study of Socrates as a historical and literary figure, with attention to his political and cultural context and primary sources by Aristophanes, Plato, and Xenophon.

courses.name: Ancient and Modern Ethics
courses.description: Engages normative ethical theories and their practical applications through ancient and modern texts, debating issues like animal rights, eugenics, abortion, and torture.

courses.name: Ancient Science and Technology: Atoms, Aqueducts, and Alchemy
courses.description: Examines the development of science and technology in the ancient Mediterranean, focusing on theory and practice in Greek city-states, Hellenistic kingdoms, and the Roman Empire within cultural, social, political, and economic contexts.

courses.name: Bath and Body Works (in Ancient Rome)
courses.description: Considers development of public baths in ancient Rome, technological and scientific innovations in their construction and water management, and connections to modern bathing facilities.

courses.name: Topics in Classical Literature
courses.description: Occasional courses or seminars in specialized topics. Consult current course descriptions for details.

courses.name: Topics in Ancient History
courses.description: Occasional courses or seminars in specialized topics. Consult current course descriptions for details.

courses.name: Topics in Ancient Philosophy
courses.description: Occasional courses or seminars in specialized topics. Consult current course descriptions for details.

courses.name: Topics in Classical Culture
courses.description: Occasional courses or seminars in specialized topics. Consult current course descriptions for details.

courses.name: Laughter and the Shape of Comedy
courses.description: Investigates the nature and psychosocial functions of laughter in Greek and Roman comedy, with readings from Aristophanes, Plautus, and Terence, supplemented by modern humor theory and collaborative playwriting and performance.

courses.name: Classical Tragedy
courses.description: Studies representative works of Greek tragic playwrights Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides, covering genre features, origins, and performance conventions.

courses.name: Myth on the Democratic Stage
courses.description: Explores how ancient Greek tragic and comic plays fostered democratic citizenship, applying analysis to modern events and media, including Miranda’s Hamilton.

courses.name: Hercules!
courses.description: Examines ancient portrayals of Hercules/Heracles through literary and material sources to understand the complex mythic figure beyond modern popular depictions.
courses.otherNotes: Can be taken as a lower-division course (CLAS 83) or an upper-division course.

courses.name: Classical Mythology in the Western Tradition
courses.description: Explores manipulation of Greek myths in Western literature from the classical period through the 20th century, focusing on the fall of Troy in works from Homer to the Coen brothers.

courses.name: Gender in Antiquity
courses.description: Investigates the representation and reality of gender in classical social, economic, political, and religious contexts.

courses.name: Cultural Heritage and Collecting Antiquities
courses.description: Studies the history of museums, collecting, and art theft in the ancient world, exploring concepts of cultural heritage, curation, and public presentation.
courses.otherNotes: Can be taken as an upper-division or lower-division course (CLAS 86).

courses.name: Greek Justice and Democratic Juries
courses.description: Examines the Athenian court system and the role of poetry, tragedy, comedy, mythology, and philosophy in Greek ideas of justice, culminating in student-run trials using ancient procedures.

courses.name: Mythic Marginalized Figures in US Culture
courses.description: Surveys modern American receptions of marginalized classical figures (e.g., Medea, Amazons) to explore how U.S. marginalized groups reinvent myth for self-representation, with both lower- and upper-division credit for Diversity core requirement.
courses.otherNotes: Both lower- and upper-division courses count for the Diversity core requirement.

courses.name: Capstone I
courses.description: Biweekly seminar on various topics, combined with initial research for senior thesis. The identification of a coherent topic of thesis, development of a detailed outline, and preparation of an annotated bibliography, are conducted under the active direction of a member of the classics faculty.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Permission of instructor and department chair required

courses.name: Capstone II
courses.description: Continuation of seminar in addition to supervised completion of the final draft, public oral presentation, and defense of the senior thesis.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Permission of instructor and department chair required

courses.name: Internships/Practica
courses.description: Independent work outside, and in coordination with, the department.

courses.name: Directed Reading/Research
courses.description: Individually designed programs of reading or research, in Latin, Greek, or classics (e.g., literature in translation or culture).

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Permission of instructor and department chair required

courses.name: Business Ethics
courses.description: A normative inquiry into the ethical issues that arise in business and how they should be managed. Attention is given to current moral issues in business and ethical theories or frameworks, their implications for these issues, and to the managerial implications. Topics may include truth in advertising, corporate social responsibility, stakeholder theory, sustainability, affirmative action, government regulation of business, quality of work-life, environmental and resource issues, and ethical codes of conduct.
courses.otherNotes: Students who take PHIL26 may not take this course for credit.

courses.name: Business Ethics
courses.description: Honors section. A normative inquiry into the ethical issues that arise in business and how they should be managed. Attention is given to current moral issues in business, ethical theories or ethical frameworks, and their implications for these issues and leadership implications. Topics may include truth in advertising, corporate social responsibility, stakeholder theory, sustainability, affirmative action, government regulation of business, quality of work-life, environmental and resource issues, and ethical codes of conduct.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Restricted to University Honors or Leavey Scholars program students.

courses.otherNotes: Students who take PHIL26 may not take this course for credit.

courses.name: Foundational Knowledge of Managing for Sustainability
courses.description: This course examines the foundational knowledge required of individuals who seek to effectively manage organizations that meet the triple bottom line: social, economic, and environmental sustainability. Students will learn the concepts critical for understanding sustainability from biological, economic, and social perspectives. Students will learn how to justify the pursuit of sustainable business practices, illustrate the role of businesses in building a just and equitable future, and demonstrate how systems thinking helps explain our world's interdependent nature.

courses.name: Foundational Skills of Managing for Sustainability
courses.description: The main focus of this course is to share the core skills necessary for professionals who work to advance sustainability in organizations and communities successfully. Students will learn to assess an organization’s sustainability practices and make appropriate strategy recommendations. Students will be able to illustrate the role of businesses in building a just and equitable future and articulate how change agents can inspire action at multiple levels to build a more sustainable world.

courses.name: Leading from the Triple Bottom Line
courses.description: This course allows students to apply the theoretical skills they have learned in previous classes to a real-world organization or “client”, and gain valuable business skills they can use in future internships or full-time roles. Students will learn the foundational principles of sustainable business and explore leadership challenges to advance social and environmental objectives within an actual business or organization. The course counts toward credit in the Design Thinking, Paradigm Shift, and Sustainability pathways.

courses.name: Professional Development Skills and Strategies Seminar
courses.description: This one-unit seminar introduces the foundational professional development skills necessary to plan and implement internship and career search strategies. By the end of the seminar, students will create a career action plan for launching an internship search and building their lifelong network.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Must be a Leavey School of Business major, have sophomore standing, or permission by instructor to enroll.

courses.name: Contemporary Business Issues
courses.description: An introduction to the nature, forms, and objectives of the contemporary business firm and its relationship to the modern business environment. Text learning is augmented by classroom discussion, connecting learning points to current events and a comprehensive business simulation.

courses.name: Foundations of Leadership: Clarifying Personal Values
courses.description: Founded on the understanding that all leadership begins with self-knowledge, this course is intended to orient students to the practice of leadership. In this course, leadership will be presented not as a position but rather a mindset, a way of doing things based on who you are and what you want to achieve. Students will be provided with an introduction to specific practices of effective leadership through directed readings and reflective writing assignments.

courses.name: Global and Cultural Environment of Business
courses.description: Examining the basic conceptual vocabulary and theories regarding today's economic, political, and social influences on international business. Topics may include international trade, financial systems, political institutions, cultural factors, corporate structure, and market entry.
courses.otherNotes: Students may not receive credit for MGMT80L or any equivalent course.

courses.name: Global Microfinance for Entrepreneurial Development
courses.description: This course introduces students to microfinance's theories, practices, and issues — a social enterprise movement that serves entrepreneurs who lack access to traditional banking services. Grounded and enhanced by systems thinking and design thinking, students will understand structural constraints, trade-offs, and paradoxes in problem-solving the current challenges facing microfinance operations. In engaging with stakeholders in microfinance, students will employ global business and management skills to empower the world’s unbanked entrepreneurs.

courses.name: Managing Human Dynamics in Organizations
courses.description: Introduction to organization theory and practice with an emphasis on organizational behavior, inclusive of the contexts of the individual, the group, and the organization as a whole.

courses.name: Managing Human Dynamics in Organizations
courses.description: Introduction to organization theory and practice with an emphasis on organizational behavior, inclusive of the contexts of the individual, the group, and the organization as a whole.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Open only to students in the Leavey Scholars Program

courses.name: Strategic Analysis—The Business Capstone
courses.description: Focuses on the processes by which managers position their businesses or assets to maximize long-term value creation and capture in the face of uncertainty, rapid change, and competition. Covers various frameworks for analyzing an industry’s structure and competitive position and developing a coherent and viable firm strategy. Requires students to integrate and extend their knowledge and skills developed throughout their coursework (e.g., marketing, finance, economics, organizational behavior, ethics, information systems, statistical analysis, operations management, accounting, etc.) into a “total” business perspective.
courses.prerequisiteCourses: ((ECON41 & ECON42) | OMIS41) & (FNCE121 | FNCE121S) & (MGMT80 | MGMT160 | MGMT160S) & (MKTG181 | MKTG181S)

courses.name: Strategic Analysis—The Business Capstone
courses.description: Focuses on the processes by which managers position their businesses or assets to maximize long-term value creation and capture in the face of uncertainty, rapid change, and competition. The course covers various frameworks for analyzing an industry’s structure and competitive position and developing a coherent and viable firm strategy. Requires students to integrate and extend their knowledge and skills developed throughout their coursework (e.g., marketing, finance, economics, organizational behavior, ethics, information systems, statistical analysis, operations management, accounting, etc.) into a “total” business perspective. Enrollment in the Leavey Scholars Program is restricted to students.
courses.prerequisiteCourses: ((ECON41 & ECON42) | OMIS41) & (FNCE121 | FNCE121S) & (MGMT80 | MGMT160 | MGMT160S) & (MKTG181 | MKTG181S)

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Enrollment in the Leavey Scholars Program is restricted to students

courses.name: Introduction to Entrepreneurship
courses.description: The course looks at the practice of business innovation and entrepreneurship, emphasizing how entrepreneurs identify opportunities, evaluate resources, build organizations, and understand the phenomena of entrepreneurship. MGMT 164 is an introductory course intended to provide a foundation regarding the role of entrepreneurship, discussing ideas about entrepreneurship and entrepreneurs in society and the economy.

courses.name: Building a Business
courses.description: This course integrates many of entrepreneurial concepts, tools, and practices. This course systematically and practically studies business creation and evaluation for new ventures and entrepreneurial projects. Students will learn to assess and shape venture ideas, convert these ideas into viable businesses, and present these businesses to external stakeholders. Topics include new venture execution plans, alternatives, and trade-offs in financing, feasibility, resource acquisition, venture growth, and harvesting. The course includes a discussion of cases, lectures, and presentations by guest lecturers who have played a role in starting new enterprises. The course builds on foundation concepts from the Introductory Entrepreneurship course. It is designed for students seriously considering launching a new venture in various contexts and for students planning to work in an early-stage venture.

courses.name: Human Resource Management
courses.description: A comprehensive review of the role and functions of human resource management departments in business organizations, with particular emphasis on selection and placement, training and development, and compensation systems.

courses.name: Venture Capitalist Essentials
courses.description: This course provides insight into the thought processes of Venture Capitalists. It will cover all aspects of deal flow, including sourcing opportunities, performing due diligence, determining valuation, and constructing term sheets. While inspired as a way to prepare students for the Venture Capital Investment Competition (held in the Winter quarter), it offers an introduction to the VC world for students interested in becoming investors and those hoping to obtain VC funds as entrepreneurs.

courses.name: Entrepreneurship and the Public Sector: Challenges and Opportunities
courses.description: Cities and local governments face many challenges as cities grow and expand. This can be both a hub for innovation and a catalyst for economic growth if entrepreneurs can understand how to build and sell solutions to these problems to governments. This course will help students to attain a fuller understanding of conducting business within various types of governments. Student(s) will interview city leaders, attend meetings, and conduct research to identify traits of successful business leaders who engage in business with various governments. This class will uncover how city officials prioritize and evaluate projects and gauge the economic effects of those decisions. This course looks at innovation and social entrepreneurship within the public sector. In addition, students can learn how to do business as an entrepreneur with a local government and know what resources are available to entrepreneurs through those local governments. Students will learn how to become a successful entrepreneur selling a product or idea to a local government and how to be change agents of innovation within public sector organizations.

courses.name: Business and Public Policy
courses.description: The impact of public policy on business and how businesses adapt to and influence public policies. Includes ideology, corporate social responsibility, government regulations, and business political activity. Lectures/discussions; case analyses.

courses.name: International Management
courses.description: Today’s business managers are challenged to set strategies, develop organizations, lead people, and control performance in a local context. They also need to understand and lead within a complex global context. This course is designed to help students: 1) understand multinational management; 2) recognize the challenges and opportunities presented by global markets; 3) implement a global strategy using organizational design, human resources management, and leadership development.

courses.name: Managerial Communication
courses.description: Interpersonal and small-group communication. Negotiating behavior. Oral and written communication. Integrates theory and skill-building through reading, case analysis, and practice.

courses.name: Social Entrepreneurship
courses.description: This course focuses on emerging enterprise models at the interface of the public, private, and nonprofit sectors. It examines theories of change and the dynamics of social innovation. It develops conceptual and practical tools for creating high-performance organizations capable of addressing seemingly intractable problems financially sustainably. Analysis of exemplary social business ventures will illustrate how the discipline of business planning can contribute to the development of social ventures that are economically viable at scale. Students will apply this knowledge to the writing and analysis of a case on—and/or service learning for—an actual social business.

courses.name: Resources, Food, and the Environment
courses.description: Exploration of relationships among food production, resource use, and the environment. Topics include food innovation, biotechnology, the green revolution, resource depletion, environmental degradation, and food safety. Also listed as ECON 101.

courses.name: Social Psychology of Leadership
courses.description: A conceptual framework for understanding leadership and opportunities for developing leadership skills. This interactive course requires personal reflection on leadership experiences.

courses.name: Flourishing at Work
courses.description: We spend a large portion of our waking lives at work. It follows that what goes on in the workplace can significantly impact our ability to flourish – to be in optimal mental and social well-being. Throughout this interactive course, we will explore various Positive Organizational Scholarship topics from the fields of Organizational Behavior and Psychology that contribute to flourishing individuals, relationships, and systems. The first half of the course focuses on promoting individual flourishing, including mindsets, values, identity, authenticity, and meaning at work. The second half of the course will focus on promoting flourishing interpersonal relationships and systems, including topics such as creating high-quality connections, psychological safety in teams, positive interpersonal emotions, networks, culture, and change.

courses.name: Sustainable Food Systems
courses.description: In this course, you will study the existing food system, issues of food access, justice, sovereignty, and opportunities to use technology and innovation to create a more just and sustainable food system. We will examine how food policy and lobbying affect food production and consumption and the role of food policy in food insecurity, health risks tied to food, and climate change. The first third of the class focuses on agricultural production, food policy, and issues of access and affordability. The second third analyzes the role of food production in climate change, supply chains, and opportunities for creating more sustainable, traceable, and transparent supply chains. In the final third of the course, we will discuss disruptive innovation opportunities in the agricultural and food technology fields as agents of change.

courses.name: Globalization and the Cultures of Innovation and Entrepreneurship
courses.description: This course introduces students to the skills, practices, and processes for understanding and managing innovation and entrepreneurship activities that span cultures worldwide. These cultural challenges include the development of an entrepreneurial mindset and adopting new organizational forms (e.g., open innovation, crowdsourcing).

courses.name: Business and Human Rights
courses.description: More and more companies are adopting human rights policies, conducting human rights due diligence, reporting on their human rights performance, and employing teams of human rights experts. Through interactive exercises, debates, case studies, and role-play, this course will provide you with the knowledge, skills and tools to identify and address a company’s human rights risks and leverage the power of business to advance human rights worldwide.

courses.name: Risk Management
courses.description: A comprehensive examination of corporate risk, including history, current practices, and the impact of risk appetites on culture (and vice versa). Coverage of risk classification, organizational risk structures, and enterprise risk management. Students will identify, prioritize, mitigate, and report risks via a hypothetical company with an analysis of actual risks impacting our global corporate landscape. Students will gain familiarity with heat maps and other planning tools and engage in drafting business continuity and disaster recovery plans. Overview of professional risk roles, responsibilities, and skills required to obtain these compelling jobs. Focus on understanding risk management roles and honing relevant skills.

courses.name: Negotiation Skills in Business
courses.description: We negotiate every day, both at work and in our personal lives. The overall goal of this course is to create a learning community where we can all improve our understanding of both the art and the science of negotiation. By learning about the research-based theories of negotiation, students will gain analytic skills in understanding negotiation principles. In preparing for the role plays assigned, students will practice selecting appropriate negotiation strategies for different contexts. By practicing negotiation in several different behavioral simulations and reflecting critically on simulation outcomes, students will gain practical skills in influencing others to secure productive agreements through negotiation.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: MGMT 160 or 160S may be taken concurrently with instructor permission

courses.name: Conscientious Capitalism
courses.description: The foundation of Conscientious Capitalism is: “To lead others, I will first learn to lead myself.” The course inspires and teaches students the role of purpose, virtue, intentionality, tenacity, and accountability in their leadership journey. The course uses three distinct but related activities to achieve this goal. Nationally renowned business, military, and civic leaders share the experiences and challenges that shaped them, their careers, and major decisions. The goal of having iconic leaders share with honesty and vulnerability is to inspire students to do the same in the course and their lives. Harvard Business School cases allow students to learn from the most critical business and policy decisions of our times. Putting students in the role of decision-maker challenges them to understand the complexity of decision-making and leadership and begins to train them for their careers post-SCU. Leadership Development Teams (LDTs) are small, mentored groups. The goal is for students to explore and share their authentic selves and develop the courage to live authentically in their careers and lives. Note: We seek evidence of a student’s ambition to make an impact and the hunger and maturity to pursue the journey of self-awareness, authenticity, and courageous action. Enrollment is based on the instructor's permission.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Enrollment is based on the instructor's permission

courses.name: Peer Educator in Management
courses.description: Work closely with the department to help students in core management classes to understand course material, think more deeply about the material, and feel less anxious about testing situations.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Student must be a declared management major.
Permission of the instructor and department chair is required before enrollment.

courses.name: Special Topics in Management
courses.description: Offered occasionally to introduce new topics not covered by existing electives. Topics generally reflect the research interests of the faculty teaching the course.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Instructor and chair must approve a written proposal one week before registration.

courses.name: Internship/Practicum
courses.description: Opportunity for students to apply managerial knowledge and skills as well as leadership skills through their internship in local organizations.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Student must complete two courses from the following: MGMT162, MGMT166, MGMT169, MGMT170, MGMT171, MGMT172, MGMT173, MGMT175, MGMT176, MGMT177, MGMT178, MGMT180, MGMT181.
Student must have completed at least 60 units before enrollment.
Approval of the undergraduate committee is required one week before registration.

courses.otherNotes: Students cannot take both MGMT198 and MGMT198E.

courses.name: Entrepreneurship Internship
courses.description: This course brings together your academic studies with real-world start-up experience. As such, the class has two segments: an on-site internship and an academic segment. The internship must be at least 10 hours per week (80 hours per quarter, starting by the first week of class). During the internship, you will help a Silicon Valley entrepreneurial organization (start-up) develop and build a new venture. Here, you will observe a new venture during its formative years. The academic component entails applying your business studies to a new firm setting. You will examine and analyze your internship experiences with your academic learning. The ultimate product of this class is an in-depth case study of the firm and its founders.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Student must have a declared entrepreneurship minor.

courses.otherNotes: Students cannot take both MGMT198 and MGMT198E.

courses.name: Directed Reading/Directed Research
courses.description: Independent projects undertaken by upper-division students with a faculty sponsor.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: A written proposal must be approved by the instructor and chair one week before registration.

courses.name: Principles of Microeconomics
courses.description: Introduction to microeconomics and its applications to business decisions and public policy. Topics include supply, demand, and the coordinating role of prices in a market economy; the behavior of business firms, including output and pricing decisions; competition and monopoly; government policies and regulations affecting markets.

courses.name: Principles of Microeconomics
courses.description: Special section of ECON 1 emphasizing environmental applications of economics. Introduction to microeconomics and its applications to business decisions and public policy.
