courses.description: This course examines global popular culture in its many forms, whether Hollywood cinema, memes on social media, music that reaches millions via streaming services, or television shows that are loved in countless countries. The course defines global popular culture in broad terms as content or communication that is shared widely across borders, consumed worldwide, or designed for a global audience. The course will address the role of communication technologies such as cinema or the internet in fashioning global popular culture. It will also focus on prominent themes in global popular culture, particularly as these relate to ethnic, cultural, or national identity, gender and sexuality, disability, and other forms of individual or collective expression.

courses.name: Asian Popular Culture: Global Influence and Political Communication
courses.description: What do BTS, Naomi Osaka and milk tea have in common? All have instigated actions for a more just world because of their fans. In this course, we will critically analyze Asian popular culture since the 1980s, using a cultural ethnographic approach. Students will apply lenses of gender, identity, globalization, and communication strategies to examine pop phenomena such as Korean Wave, Cool Japan, Taiwanese and Cantonese popular music, and anime. Students will engage in online videos critique, reflections and presentations on Asian pop culture’s global influences for justice.

courses.name: Disability in Global Popular Culture
courses.description: This upper-division seminar centers on the treatment of disability across a range of global cultural and media forms, including cinema, comics, art, music, and online communities of and for the disabled. The course views disability through the following theoretical perspectives: as a medical condition that marks it as deviant from the normal; as a socially constructed category of difference, like race or sexual orientation; and as a legal and social category of identity, according to which being disabled is akin to possessing an ethnicity. We will critically examine how characters in global media culture both reflect and challenge the perspectives on disability identified above. We will unpack how ideas of disability as a type of difference intersect with perceptions of racial, ethnic, gender, national, and sexual difference, whether the intellectual inferiority of colonized peoples, and the newly resurgent scientific emphasis on innate biological differences between men and women. Course materials include readings from social theory, media and cultural studies, and historical studies of disability. Additionally, we will read, listen to, view, and analyze a number of media and cultural texts, including film, episodes of animated television series, iconic works of art, musical compositions, and public online forums of communities of self-identified disabled groups.

courses.name: Global Music: Profits, Poetry, and Politics
courses.description: Global music as a broad category encompasses music produced in different parts of the world that circulates globally and music that is a product of influences from multiple cultures. This upper-division seminar course will engage with the past and present of global music, thus defined, from three angles. First, it will examine the economics of the global music industry, specifically how the principle of maximizing profitability influences the image of musical artists, music content, and cultural taste. Second, the course will analyze the aesthetic appeal of music from different traditions, in terms of the impact of lyrics, melodies, and other elements of songs and compositions. And, third, it will consider how global music reflects and, in turn, shapes politics and power relations, whether in everyday life or in movements for social change and political protests. The course will look at how musical genres from particular areas of the world have traveled and taken on new forms in other parts of the globe, for example, how African rhythms have shaped jazz and rock or how American protest songs of the 60s have been deployed as powerful statements against authoritarianism continents away. We will pay special attention to the impact of internet-related developments on global music, such as the disruption to the industry caused by streaming technologies and platforms like Spotify, new forums now available to musicians, such as YouTube, and direct access to global audiences without traditional channels of distribution. The global musical traditions covered include jazz, Afro-Cuban and Latin music, rock, hip-hop, fusion, Indian film songs, Flamenco, Rai, disco, EDM, and global percussion traditions. No technical knowledge or background in music theory is required for the course.

courses.name: Communication, Development, and Social Change
courses.description: How does communication content and technology solve problems of global poverty and social change? This course addresses the theories, policies, and practices that help explain the success or failure of new communication technologies in “helping the disenfranchised” achieve a better life for themselves both in the global South and North. We will examine the relationship between media technologies and social change/development initiatives with a focus on liberal, participatory and critical approaches. We will always ground theoretical perspectives in specific examples of development communication projects and strategies.

courses.name: Global Media and Postcolonial Identity
courses.description: Paying careful attention to the meaning of the term “postcolonial” in different historical and geographical contexts, this course undertakes a critical analysis of media representations of national and cultural identity in postcolonial societies in Africa, Latin America, and Asia. Evaluates the ways in which media constructions of national identity intersect with understandings of gender, race, religion, and ethnicity. A key focus area of the course is the experience of diasporic postcolonial communities as represented in media.

courses.name: Identity, Privacy, and Politics in the Digital Age
courses.description: This course examines the dynamics of communication in new media networks and forums, covering the overlapping categories of social networks, social media, blogs, microblogs, portals, and collective knowledge initiatives such as Wikipedia. We will analyze communication practices in new media with a focus on the following four areas: (1) convergence and links between forms of media and technology, such as mobile phones, computers, and books; (2) changing conceptions of self and community; (3) emerging of paradigms of creative collaboration and artistic and intellectual production; and (4) posed challenges about privacy, copyright, and intellectual ownership. We will examine these areas from a global perspective, keeping in mind both the global nature of new media networks and communities, and the particular trajectories of new media communicative practices in different global contexts. In this regard, we will also address the social, ethical, and political consequences of the “digital divide” between those who are networked and connected in this world and those who lack access to it.

courses.name: Media and Social Movements
courses.description: In recent times, we have seen a series of social movements in the US and different parts of the world such as #BlackLivesMatter, #MeToo, environmental movements, Silicon Valley protests and others. In this course, we will explore social movements in increasingly digital and “networked” environments with a focus on "real world" organizing for social change. We will draw from a range of readings, films, podcasts, and social media.
courses.otherNotes: Qualifies for Civic Engagement Core and two pathways: Democracy & Race, Place and Social Inequalities.

courses.name: Food and Communication
courses.description: This upper-division seminar explores the rich, multifaceted, and fascinating relationship between food and communication from the following complementary perspectives. One, we will analyze food as a form of communication, reflecting on what food tells us about society, culture, and identity. What kinds of tensions—for example, between individual choice and collective obligations, national identity and cosmopolitan aspirations, tradition and modernity—are associated with food-related practices? How do we respond to the competing ethical claims of vegetarianism and meat-eating? Two, we will examine communication about food, closely reading representations of food in different forms of media, including art, cinema, television shows, and graphic novels. And, finally, we will look at food as the site and space of cultural encounters, as a marker of both similarity in difference. Course readings and materials are drawn from a number of disciplinary backgrounds, including cultural studies, sociology, media studies, and food studies, and from a range of media genres. Within this broad framework, students will develop an original thesis related to food and communication and produce a high-quality research paper by the end of the seminar.

courses.name: Communication, Identity, and Citizenship in Asia
courses.description: Citizenship is about belonging. With abundant transnational cultural influences, multinational treaties, and cross-border marriages, the belonging process is complicated. In this course, we will discuss how historically marginalized groups such as immigrants, LGBTQ+, women, and indigenous groups experience belonging, specifically in Asia. We will examine their struggles with citizenship in the larger context of east-west interactions. Finally, we will relate these experiences to those in the United States. Students will learn how the thinking and making of citizens has changed, and are encouraged to imagine how it can continue to change in the future.

courses.name: Journalism Practicum
courses.description: For writers and editors of The Santa Clara. Students review the student newspaper, offer practical advice, and gain experience in journalism. The Santa Clara staff members assist in teaching students skills in news, sports, feature writing and reporting, and techniques of design and production. Class members meet once a week and are expected to spend at least three hours a week in newspaper work.

courses.name: Independent Filmmaking Practicum
courses.description: This course helps emerging filmmakers, artists, and designers in all disciplines; entrepreneurs; students focusing on marketing, public relations, and journalism; and film lovers to advance their skills in the art and business of filmmaking and media. Students produce real-world short projects: fiction, commercial, and documentary. The practicum is designed to give students hands-on experience in producing, directing, cinematography, production design, editing, sound, music, acting, and screenwriting. Students will also help organize the Genesis student film festival.

courses.name: Online Journalism Practicum
courses.description: Designed to get students involved with journalism via digital media. Students report, write, edit, broadcast, and promote news, arts, and entertainment content. Work may air on KSCU, in The Santa Clara student newspaper, websites, or the practicum blog. Students will also learn the basics of digital recording and receive a basic introduction to studio production and new media.

courses.name: Yearbook Practicum
courses.description: For editors and principal staff members of the University’s yearbook, The Redwood. Principles of photojournalism, magazine graphic design, and book production. The Redwood staff members assist in teaching skills in reporting, writing, production, and design.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Class members must meet once a week and spend at least three hours a week in yearbook work.

courses.name: Forensics Practicum
courses.description: Supervised activity in forensics. Includes competition in debate and various speaking events: persuasive, expository, extemporaneous, impromptu speaking, and oral interpretation.

courses.name: Peer Educator
courses.description: This course is offered for students who assist in teaching courses in the department for academic credit rather than pay.

courses.name: Senior Portfolio
courses.description: A 2-unit course that communication majors complete during their final year. Students will create an online portfolio and write a reflection paper describing how their coursework has shaped who they are and their vocation choices.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Completion of all lower-division required courses.
Completion of three of six upper-division Communication electives.

courses.name: Internship
courses.description: A forum where students can learn how they can best apply classroom instruction to their career objectives through academically supported work experience. Internships at Santa Clara University are closely monitored for appropriateness and practical application. Internships should encourage career skills and professional growth; they should not be just another job. Internships are an important and integral part of the communication craft and serve to introduce the student to the range of opportunities afforded a degree in the discipline. Students are expected to represent the University in a professional manner and to act responsibly with the client and the assignments.

courses.name: Directed Research/Creative Project
courses.description: Students arrange to work with a faculty member for directed reading or a research project in communication theory, research, ethics, etc. Creative projects may also be arranged in television, print, or another applied area. The Department also uses this number for communication electives taken in study abroad programs.

otherRequirements.requirementDescription: Written proposal, course meeting schedule, and readings must be approved by instructor and chair prior to registration.

requirements.requirementDescription: Goals: Critical Thinking, Complexity, Communication; Meta-Goals: Information Literacy and Intentional Learning; Learning Objectives: 1. Read and analyze texts for audience, speaker/writer, purpose, message, and context; 2. Compose rhetorically effective nonfiction texts for different audiences in different modes of presentation; 3. Compose texts that resist overly simplistic binary thinking by engaging various perspectives; 4. Use writing processes as tools for learning and discovery.

Goals: Critical Thinking, Complexity, Communication; Meta-Goals: Information Literacy and Intentional Learning; Learning Objectives: 1. Locate and select information that genuinely considers multiple, credible perspectives; 2. Demonstrate an engaged, ethical approach to the use of sources, including accurate citation; 3. Compose texts that effectively integrate sources for a clear purpose, audience, and occasion in different modes of presentation; 4. Use writing and information literacy as tools for learning and discovery.

Goals: Global Cultures, Arts & Humanities, Critical Thinking, Perspective; Learning Objectives: 1. Identify significant elements of the cultures examined; 2. Recognize the complexity of the cultures examined; 3. Analyze and/or interpret significant objects, texts, ideas, issues and/or events in their historical contexts using at least one disciplinary method; 4. Examine and analyze both shared and diverse human experiences across cultures and historical periods to comprehend the relevance of the past to the cultural present.

Goals: Global Cultures, Arts & Humanities, Critical Thinking, Perspective; Learning Objectives: 1. Make connections between the cultures and objects, texts, ideas, issues, and/or events examined in C&I 1 and 2; 2. Demonstrate understanding of the complexity and/or larger contexts of the cultures examined; 3. Question and/or evaluate the effects cultural understanding has on interpretation of the objects, texts, ideas, and/or events; 4. Examine and analyze both shared and diverse human experiences across cultures and historical periods, demonstrating awareness of relevance to students’ own worldview, cultural assumptions, and values.

Goals: Critical Thinking, Mathematics & Quantitative Reasoning, Communication, Complexity; Learning Objectives: 1. Demonstrate problem-solving skills including interpreting problem situations, choosing among mathematical methods, persisting in the face of difficulty, and presenting full solutions with justification; 2. Approach mathematical ideas/problems from multiple perspectives (e.g., using connections between geometry, algebra, and numerical computation; applying theory to applications; distinguishing between formal proofs and less formal arguments); 3. Demonstrate understanding of mathematical content, including its limitations, beyond mere fluency with symbols, language, and formulas.

requirements.requirementName: Mathematics for Leavey School of Business (pre-June 1, 2024)
requirements.requirementDescription: Students enrolled (or previously enrolled) at SCU prior to June 1, 2024 must take either MATH 30 and MATH 31 or MATH 11 and MATH 12.

requirements.requirementName: Mathematics for Leavey School of Business (post-June 1, 2024)
requirements.requirementDescription: Students starting at SCU on or after June 1, 2024 must take one mathematics course: MATH 11 or MATH 30; additionally, Economics or Finance majors must take a second calculus course (MATH 12 or MATH 31).
Engineering students must take MATH 11 and MATH 12.

requirements.requirementName: Mathematics for College of Arts and Sciences – Life Science majors
requirements.requirementDescription: Life Science students take MATH 35 and MATH 36.

requirements.requirementName: Mathematics for College of Arts and Sciences (except Life Science majors)
requirements.requirementDescription: Arts and Sciences (except Life Science majors) students select any course from the Mathematics list.

Goals: Global Cultures, Critical Thinking, Complexity, Religious Reflection; Learning Objectives: 1. Describe and compare central religious ideas and practices from at least two distinct cultures or communities; 2. Use critical approaches to reflect on personal beliefs and the religious dimensions of human existence.

Goals: Communication, Perspective; Learning Objectives: 1. Demonstrate skill in the use of a modern or classical language for authentic communicative purposes; 2. Demonstrate understanding of and sensitivity to cultural products, practices, and perspectives exhibited in the language studied. Students satisfy the requirement by completing the level required by their major or by two years of high school study (for Engineering BS).

Critical Thinking, Complexity, Communication. Students will read and write with a critical point of view; compose texts demonstrating intellectual and creative rigor; independently locate and use credible evidence; and understand and manipulate their writing processes.

Critical Thinking, Complexity, Communication. Students will read and write with a critical point of view; compose texts demonstrating intellectual and creative rigor; independently locate and use credible evidence; and understand and manipulate their writing processes.

Critical Thinking, Complexity, Communication. Students will read and write with a critical point of view; compose texts demonstrating intellectual and creative rigor; independently locate and use credible evidence; and understand and manipulate their writing processes.

Social Justice, Civic Life, Perspective, Civic Engagement. Students will recognize the importance of lifelong responsible citizenship and civic engagement; appreciate formal and informal community knowledge; and understand social realities and injustices.

requirements.requirementName: Pathway Course Requirement for CAS and LSB First-Year Students
requirements.requirementDescription: Complete four Pathway courses (at least 16 units). If a Pathway includes courses less than four units, more than four courses will be necessary.
requirements.appliesTo: College of Arts and Sciences and Leavey School of Business (First-year students and transfer students with fewer than 44 transfer units)

requirements.requirementName: Pathway Course Requirement for Engineering Majors
requirements.requirementDescription: Complete three Pathway courses (at least 12 units). If a Pathway includes courses less than four units, more than three courses will be necessary.

requirements.requirementName: Pathway Course Requirement for Transfer Students with 44 or More Transfer Units
requirements.requirementDescription: Complete three Pathway courses (at least 12 units). If a Pathway includes courses less than four units, more than three courses will be necessary.
requirements.appliesTo: Transfer students with 44 or more transfer units

requirements.requirementDescription: All courses for the Pathway must be completed at SCU.
No more than the equivalent of two 4- or 5-unit courses may be in the same subject. The remaining courses and units to complete the Pathway must be from different subjects.
ENVS, ETHN, CHST, PHSC, and WGST are exempt from the two-course same-subject rule because courses in these areas are inherently interdisciplinary.
A Pathway may contain no more than two courses from the Cultures & Ideas sequence (C&I 1, 2, 3) or the Religion, Theology, & Culture sequence (RTC 1, 2, 3).
Only one course in a Pathway may be a Foundations course. (C&I 1 and 2 and RTC 1 are Foundations courses; C&I 3, RTC 2 and 3 are not.)
Students will complete only one Pathway, even if some courses are appropriate for more than one Pathway.
Students may apply no more than one study abroad course toward their Pathway.
Any course a student wants to include within a Pathway must have been approved for the Pathway.

Goals: Arts & Humanities, Complexity, Communication, Collaboration. Learning Objectives: (1) Learn and apply basic artistic techniques and aesthetic principles to create works of art; (2) Demonstrate an understanding of how artistic creation enables the expression of human ideals, challenges, and desires; (3) Reflect on and analyze works of art and the creative process, individually and collaboratively.

Goals: Arts & Humanities, Complexity, Communication, Collaboration. Learning Objectives: (1) Learn and apply basic artistic techniques and aesthetic principles to create works of art; (2) Demonstrate an understanding of how artistic creation enables the expression of human ideals, challenges, and desires; (3) Reflect on and analyze works of art and the creative process, individually and collaboratively.

Goals: Arts & Humanities, Complexity, Communication, Collaboration. Learning Objectives: (1) Learn and apply basic artistic techniques and aesthetic principles to create works of art; (2) Demonstrate an understanding of how artistic creation enables the expression of human ideals, challenges, and desires; (3) Reflect on and analyze works of art and the creative process, individually and collaboratively.

Goals: Civic Life, Collaboration, Civic Engagement, Communication. Learning Objectives: (1) Critically evaluate and express reasoned opinions about the role of public organizations; (2) Analyze and evaluate civic issues by engaging in active and collaborative learning with peers through cooperative class work, real‐world observation or participation, or work with civic organizations.

Goals: Civic Life, Collaboration, Civic Engagement, Communication. Learning Objectives: (1) Critically evaluate and express reasoned opinions about the role of public organizations; (2) Analyze and evaluate civic issues by engaging in active and collaborative learning with peers through cooperative class work, real‐world observation or participation, or work with civic organizations.

Goals: Civic Life, Collaboration, Civic Engagement, Communication. Learning Objectives: (1) Critically evaluate and express reasoned opinions about the role of public organizations; (2) Analyze and evaluate civic issues by engaging in active and collaborative learning with peers through cooperative class work, real‐world observation or participation, or work with civic organizations.

Goals: Global Cultures, Diversity, Critical Thinking, Perspective. Learning Objectives: (3.1) Understand non-Western cultures in global/diasporic contexts; (3.2) Analyze challenges as cultures interact.

Goals: Global Cultures, Diversity, Critical Thinking, Perspective. Learning Objectives: (3.1) Understand non-Western cultures in global/diasporic contexts; (3.2) Analyze challenges as cultures interact.

Goals: Global Cultures, Diversity, Critical Thinking, Perspective. Learning Objectives: (3.1) Understand non-Western cultures in global/diasporic contexts; (3.2) Analyze challenges as cultures interact.

Goals: Diversity, Perspective, Social Justice, Complexity. Learning Objectives: (1) Describe diverse experiences in the U.S.; (2) Discuss concepts perpetuating inequity; (3) Examine diversity intersections; (4) Analyze power and privilege differences.

Goals: Arts & Humanities, Critical Thinking, Complexity, Ethical Reasoning. Learning Objectives: (1) Reason ethically using major theories; (2) Analyze and apply ethical theories to significant issues; (3) Appreciate nuance and precision in moral reasoning; (4) Reflect on personal ethical decisions and roles as responsible members of human community.

Goals: Arts & Humanities, Critical Thinking, Complexity, Ethical Reasoning. Learning Objectives: (1) Reason ethically using major theories; (2) Analyze and apply ethical theories to significant issues; (3) Appreciate nuance and precision in moral reasoning; (4) Reflect on personal ethical decisions and roles as responsible members of human community.

Goals: Scientific Inquiry, Complexity, Critical Thinking, Mathematical & Quantitative Reasoning. Learning Objectives: (1) Understand central natural science concepts; (2) Apply scientific reasoning/methods; (3) Interpret scientific data; (4) Recognize limitations of evidence.

Goals: Critical Thinking, Complexity, Religious Reflection. Learning Objectives: (2.1) Analyze complex religious phenomena; (2.2) Integrate and compare disciplinary approaches; (2.3) Clarify and express beliefs through critical inquiry.

Goals: Critical Thinking, Ethical Reasoning, Religious Reflection, Perspective. Learning Objectives: (3.1) Identify diverse perspectives and evaluate ethical implications; (3.2) Evaluate and apply religious insights to societal issues.

Goals: Scientific Inquiry, Science & Technology, Critical Thinking, Complexity. Learning Objectives: (1) Comprehend relevant science/technology and inquiry; (2) Analyze mutual influence between science/technology and society.

Goals: Scientific Inquiry, Science & Technology, Critical Thinking, Complexity. Learning Objectives: (1) Comprehend relevant science/technology and inquiry; (2) Analyze mutual influence between science/technology and society.

Goals: Scientific Inquiry, Complexity, Critical Thinking, Mathematical & Quantitative Reasoning. Learning Objectives: (1) Explain theories, concepts, methods; (2) Apply scientific reasoning to social phenomena; (3) Interpret and evaluate social data.

pathways.name: Applied Ethics
pathways.description: This pathway invites students to explore the application of critical ethical thinking to real world problems, deepening their understanding of vocational and educational choices. Courses address ethical issues in areas such as communication, economics and business, healthcare, politics, gender, sustainability, diplomacy, and war. They include sustained discussion of practical ethical dimensions, drawing on diverse theories and methodologies across disciplines to support critical consideration of real-life dilemmas and reasoned solutions to controversial moral issues.

pathways.name: Children, Family and Society
pathways.description: Courses in this Pathway will offer students the opportunity to learn about children from several disciplinary perspectives, to learn about the societal and cultural structures that provide the context for development such as the family and school, and to gain experience working with children in the community. Students may discover that the courses lead them on a pathway to vocation: as they become both more informed and more passionate about children, they will be attracted to professional fields that address the needs of children and families, such as teaching, counseling, social work, family law, public health, and pre-med. In sum, students who love children and want to work with them will have the opportunity for more in depth learning about the knowledge and personal commitment that are required for such a vocation.

pathways.name: Public Policy
pathways.description: Public Policy examines laws, regulations, and governmental structures that shape taxation, subsidies, ethics, and the public sector. It explores political philosophies, economic theories, and implementation strategies underlying public decision-making and policy design.

pathways.name: Politics & Religion
pathways.description: This Pathway considers the relation of politics and religion in global perspective from early times to the present. Courses explore themes of social, governmental, and religious systems; economics; the arts; literature; gender; race; science; the environment; and globalism.

pathways.name: American Studies
pathways.description: American Studies is an interdisciplinary approach to the study of the United States, past and present. Students approach the study of American cultures through such diverse fields as history, literature, religious studies, art, economics, and environmental studies, and might focus on such topics as popular culture and material culture, ethnic studies and gender studies, empire and globalization. American Studies students analyze America's relations with the rest of the world, the construction and deconstruction of American identities, and changing and competing definitions of America (including critiques of the very name “American Studies”). We encourage students to intentionally craft a four-course cluster around a theme or topic of special interest to them. Such intentional focus will also make it easier for students to complete the reflection paper.

pathways.name: The Digital Age
pathways.description: The Digital Age emphasizes electronic manipulation of information shaping the global economy and society. This Pathway explores digital information technology and its pervasive role, deepening understanding of the interplay between social, moral, political, and cultural values and our digital society through integrative, cross-disciplinary learning.

pathways.name: Islamic Studies
pathways.description: Courses investigate Islam as a religion, civilization, and diverse cultural traditions across disciplines, covering theological interpretations, politics and religion, anthropological perspectives, history and cultural phenomena, Islamic themes in literature and the arts, and interreligious/cross-cultural contacts.

pathways.name: Paradigm Shifts & the Nature of Human Knowing
pathways.description: This interdisciplinary pathway examines moments when disciplines undergo dramatic changes in thought—paradigm shifts—and explores how knowledge is constructed, interpreted, and understood across fields. Through courses that depart from or reinforce accepted norms of knowing, students reflect on their own learning, identify common threads across disciplines, and connect these insights to personal educational and vocational paths.

pathways.name: Values in Science & Technology
pathways.description: This pathway invites students to critically engage with the social values and context of science and technology. It includes lower and upper division courses across sciences, engineering, social sciences, and humanities to examine how science and technology function as social forces and how social values influence them.

pathways.name: Law & Social Justice
pathways.description: The Law and Social Justice Pathway offers students a cross-disciplinary opportunity to learn about and focus on issues related to social justice particularly from a legal perspective. It is designed for those considering law school, legal services, government, social services, or public service careers, providing both theoretical foundations and practical community-based experiences.

pathways.name: Cinema Studies
pathways.description: Courses in this Pathway help students engage in the critical study of film and television history, theory, aesthetics, and production. Students explore national cinemas, international film movements, major and minor filmmakers, film and media theory, the economic, legal, and political forces governing the film and television industries, and the relationship between film, television, the arts and culture. They analyze and reflect on existing films and television shows or create new films or videos, and compare film and television to other art forms such as novels or plays. A main goal is to deepen understanding of how cinema shapes and is shaped by its culture, enriched by contact with history, literature, foreign cultures, philosophy, and theology.

pathways.name: Beauty
pathways.description: We value love, money, fun, faith, work, thought, inspiration, community, and friendship. Why? Is it enough to say that these things help us to survive in the world, or do we value these things for reasons that are much more difficult to explain? In this Pathway, we explore a more complex and controversial motivation for human energy, an interest in beauty. It is an interest we do not always embrace, often preferring the less risky concepts of cute or cool. But while Thomas Kinkade and Kenny G might fit right in, Beethoven sonatas and Michelangelo sculptures are difficult to characterize with such perfunctory terms. We encourage students setting off on this Pathway to consider whether there is a realm of the beautiful and, if there is, identify some of its characteristics and manifestations.

pathways.name: Human Rights in a Global World
pathways.description: This Pathway examines theories and applications of universal human rights across historical and contemporary contexts. Students engage with issues of discrimination based on race, gender, caste, ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, age, and questions about the scope and enforceability of rights—from the United Nations Declaration to debates over cultural bias and competing social claims. The curriculum probes complex legal, ethical, and social challenges surrounding who qualifies as a rights‐bearing human being and how rights for one group can infringe on those of another.

pathways.name: Design Thinking
pathways.description: Design thinking provides a holistic, interdisciplinary approach to developing new products and processes by creatively synthesizing technology and sustainable enterprise considerations. It can be applied across the arts, humanities, sciences, social sciences, business, and engineering to address real-world problems—from consumer products to global issues like climate change and healthcare.

pathways.name: Gender, Globalization, & Empire
pathways.description: The Gender, Globalization and Empire Pathway provides students with an opportunity to examine the production of raced and gendered subjects through a series of interdisciplinary courses linking ideas about gender to imperial pasts, postcolonial theories, social and political constructions of citizenship, diverse religious movements and the intricacies of globalization. Courses emphasize historicizing and contextualizing individual experiences within categories of race, sex, class, culture and nation, exploring issues such as orientalism, modernity, hegemony, nationalism, militarism, fundamentalism and the gendered division of labor.

pathways.name: Sustainability
pathways.description: Sustainability is most often defined as meeting our present needs without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their needs. The recognition that sustainability is an imperative that must be met stems from the fact that humans are using the earth’s resources and degrading its ecosystems in ways that compromise the health and well-being of future generations and the planet. The Sustainability Pathway allows students to learn about sustainability from multiple disciplinary perspectives and in interdisciplinary ways, integrating the interconnected ideals of viable ecological integrity, viable economies, and equity and justice through themes such as human connections to the physical and natural world, natural systems function, ethics and values, technological and economic relationships, motivating sustainable behavior, and critical engagement with sustainability issues.

pathways.name: Leading People, Organization & Social Change
pathways.description: Courses in this Pathway examine theories of leadership and cultivate the skills and competencies necessary to lead people and organizations to achieve social change. Students will be exposed to historical and current examples of leaders and their impact on the communities they serve. Students will also explore and research methods leaders use to inspire, initiate and accomplish change in various formal, social and community roles and settings. Throughout the experience, students will be challenged to think and reflect on the type of leader they believe they should become in order to achieve their goals while addressing the needs of the greater community.

pathways.name: Democracy
pathways.description: This Pathway focuses on the history, theory, and practice of democracy as a political philosophy and a way of allocating power within political systems, social systems, and non-governmental institutions, helping students draw conclusions about democracy’s contributions and practice in contemporary institutions relevant to their major or vocation.

pathways.name: Feeding the World
pathways.description: The Feeding the World pathway focuses on the complex interrelationships among food production, food consumption, hunger, poverty, and the environment. Students explore how the production, consumption, and distribution of food resources are impacted by factors including resource availability, income levels, and environmental degradation. The pathway examines food production in fragile environments, sustainability of subsistence systems, and the role of agricultural development in reducing global hunger and poverty.

pathways.name: Justice & the Arts
pathways.description: This pathway engages students with historical and contemporary works of music, theatre, dance, visual art, and literature as critical or instigative responses to issues of justice. Through analysis, reflection, live performance, and creative work, students explore how art fosters empathy, challenges perception, and shapes a more just society.

pathways.name: Gender, Sexuality, & the Body
pathways.description: This Pathway allows students to explore cultural representations and social constructions of the gendered human body and sexuality. Courses include significant diversity components and emphasize social justice across intersections such as ethnicity, age, and physical ability.

pathways.name: Race, Place & Social Inequalities
pathways.description: Courses in this Pathway examine the intersections of race and ethnicity, place, and social inequalities in both transnational comparative contexts and within the United States. Topics include racial and ethnic communities, Whiteness and privilege, social constructs of place, and how social inequalities shape political mobilization, public policy, identities, social movements, community formation, race relations, and artistic expressions.

pathways.name: Vocation
pathways.description: The Vocation Pathway helps students explore questions of gifts, talents, values, and contribution to pursue a meaningful life and vocation. Through diverse perspectives and reflective practice, students discern their strengths and deepest values, develop clarity and courage, and learn to make a positive difference in the world.

pathways.name: Global Health
pathways.description: This pathway explores human health and the biological, environmental, psychological, and social factors that impact it, with particular attention to global issues such as infectious and chronic disease, healthcare, mental health, pollution and environmental degradation, agriculture and nutrition, and poverty and social inequalities. All courses include discussion of the social context of health issues and issues germane to resource-poor regions of the world, highlighting the links between health and social justice.
